© 2016 North Jersey Media Group November 8, 2016 Last updated: Tuesday, November 8, 2016, 1:54 PM Ten residents seek seats during Garfield's first November election By Kristie Cattafi Staff Writer |  Community News (Garfield Edition) Garfield will be holding it first November council election after the governing body approved to change the date this year. Ten residents are competing for five, four-year seats on Nov. 8. Incumbents Gaetana (Tana) Raymond, Glenn Mati, Louis Aloia, Joseph Delaney III and Franic Calandriello are seeking re-election along with residents Erin Delaney, Richard Rigoglioso, Romi Herrera, Nikolce Milevski and Tony Lio. Louis Aloia Aloia has served as mayor of Garfield from 1996 to 2000 and as a councilman from 2000 to present. He is married to his wife, Rosemarie, with six children and six grandchildren. He is the owner and manager of Aloia Funeral Home. Aloia said in the last four years he is most proud of the city's redevelopment including the General Pulaski statue at the new Garfield River Drive Park, Garden State Signature Place, Walmart, Applebees, McDonalds, and Wawa. He said he is also proud of the council for saving and maintaining the Garfield VFW. He said the VFW exemplifies community spirit and service. If re-elected Aloia wants to see future development of the city especially with the new police department and safety of town. He said he also wants to establish more fire vehicles and create a better public safety net for the city. Future redevelopment projects he wants to focus on is getting the Monroe Street complex developed. He said developing the Monroe Street area will be key because it will increase value in the first ward. He said the next four years will be focusing on developing the first ward and "making it equally blessed" like the rest of the city. He is a founding member of the Garfield Redevelopment Authority, is a former president of Garfield UNICO, was the director of the Garfield Chamber of Commerce for 10 years, is a former member of the Garfield Planning Board, housing authority and library board and the recipient of the Garfield Mayor's Award for outstanding civic contributions. Frank Calandriello Calandriello is running with Glenn Mati and Louis Aloia under the slogan "Working for you 2016." He has served on the council for 20 years, including three consecutive terms as mayor. He is the president of Frankie's Express Moving and F&M Leasing, a 55-year family owned business. He was inducted into the New Jersey State League of Municipalities in 2011 in the Mayoral Hall of Fame. He is been trustee of the Garfield Boys & Girls Club for the last 25 years, a Garfield Jr. Boilermaker coach for the last 20 years, and a coach for various sports for several years. He is also a founding member of the Garfield Redevelopment Authority, former chairman of the Garfield Housing Authority and former planning board member. Calandriello said he is very proud of his voting record. In 2016, the municipal tax was reduced. He said he felt the taxes were stabilized but a reduction is very "unique." He said the tax reduction was accomplished with the city's redevelopment efforts. Calandriello said he was a founding member of the redevelopment committee in 2001 where they successfully identified 54 acres. Since then, the redevelopment agency has brought in $5 million in developer fees to the city, including $2.8 million toward the new police station. The redevelopment has also brought new jobs to the city with the Passaic Street shopping center stores, Wawa and Price Rite. "During the recession across the state tax revenues dropped with tax appeals, but Garfield stayed steady with redevelopment," Calandriello said. "We still continue to do a great job bringing in new ratables and maintaining a healthy surplus." He said in the last four years the city also improved their bond rating to AA- and received millions in grants saving the taxpayers money. Something he is very proud of is holding the developer Vornado accountable for their "good faith commitment" of a property donation that is now being used for the dog park on Hobart Place. The grant money originally awarded for the dog park is now being used for River Drive's second phase of the river restoration project and being used to acquire land. "I have always supported smart development without compromising the quality of life for residents," he said. He said that is why he voted against using eminent domain in the first ward. "I'm in favor of redevelopment just not the eminent domain aspect," he said. "People have the right to stay in their homes or at least be compensated fairly." In the last four years, he has supported new protective lightening warning at 20th Century field, the General Pulaski statue and Garfield River Drive Park, hiring more police officers and getting more fire and safety vehicles, the VFW with refurbishing the building, library improvements, and the council of affordable housing program. If re-elected, Calendriello said he will continue the superfund fight along with state and federal legislatures for funding of the cleanup until the city is chromium free. He also wants to see Passaic Street redeveloped without using eminent domain, and continue redevelopment especially on Monroe Street. He also wants to continue monitoring and improving the quality of water, especially the safety and quality while keeping water affordable. Calandriello will also like to see the recreation center expand with the hours and activities. "I also want to continue to support our police and firefighters who work so hard every day protecting our citizens and ensuring our public safety," he said. Joe Delaney Delaney said when he first became mayor four years ago his focus was increasing the redevelopment in the city. "The Passaic Street redevelopment was at a standstill with only the Walmart and Applebee's," Delaney said. "Within my first month as mayor, McDonald's called and after it being previously denied I was able to push it forward despite resistance from the planning board." After McDonald's came to the location, Delaney said other businesses like Marshalls, Burlington Coat Factory and Pet Smart followed. "I don't want to wait another 10 years for redevelopment to move forward. I know government moves slowly but in Garfield sometimes it moves at a snail's pace and that's what I'm totally against," Delaney said. Delaney said if re-elected, he wants to focus on the redevelopment of Passaic Street. He said six months ago a plan for that area was voted down and it hasn't been spoken about since. "If we don't redevelop Passaic Street now, it will look the same if not worse 10 years from now," he said. He said he also wants to focus on hiring more employees for the department of public works. He said he recently voted against purchasing half a million dollars of equipment for the DPW because there needs to be more employees especially with redevelopment in the city increasing. He said he also wants to create a code enforcer to go around the city enforcing ordinances that the city already has like putting out garbage too early and cleaning up after pets. He said it may seem small, but enforcement of minor things will make a huge impact to the city and alleviate the police who are busy. Delaney said one of the quality-of-life issues he also wants to make a priority is speeding throughout the city. He said the council needs to encourage the police department to write more speeding tickets and do more radar posts. As a representative on the Bergen County Community Development Board for more than 12 years, he was able to obtain more than $10 million in grants to improve Garfield's parks, roads and community buildings. Delaney said he was also instrumental in moving the May municipal election to November. In the next four years, Delaney wants to focus on the redevelopment on Passaic Street and to turn into a downtown shopping area. He also wants to get the entire community more involved with more events in the city like fireworks, festivals, community weekends, movie nights and events at the River Drive Park. Delaney is also running with his daughter. "Some members of the sitting council have said my daughter is too young, but I feel we need some new young and fresh ideas," he said. "If we don't come up with these ideas then the city will be stagnant. We have to look towards the future. Our slogan is 'Our Future is Now.' We don't want to put off for tomorrow what we can do now. Erin brings fresh, educated ideas to the council and that's what we definitely need." Delaney is a lifelong resident of Garfield, a parishioner of Most Holy Name Church and is married with five children who all graduated from the Garfield Public School system. He has served the community as mayor, deputy mayor, councilman and board of education trustee. He is also a member the YMCA board of directors and the Boys & Girl' Club Coaches Association for more than 20 years, he's also a Garfield PBA Silver Card recipient. Erin Delaney Delnaey graduated from Garfield High School in 2009 and was a member of the National Honor Society and Top 20 Seniors. She received her bachelor's degree in psychology and master's degree in public administration. She is the founder of the Garfield Stigma Free Committee and member of the Garfield Prevention Coalition and the Garfield Municipal Alliance. She has worked in the field of substance abuse for four years for Partners in Prevention, the Bergen County Office of Alcohol and Drug Dependency and The Center of Alcohol and Drug Resources. Delaney also has experience in grant work, community organization, community outreach, program development, coalition management and event planning. While working at The Center for Alcohol and Drug Resources, a five year $125,000 per year grant was secured for Garfield. She has been a volunteer in several community organizations such as Food for Thought Healthy Living, Garfield Clean Communities, and a volunteer coach with various youth organizations. Delaney has been instrumental in bringing various programs to the city at no cost to the residents such as Strengthening Families, Second Step, Training for Intervention Procedures, Mental Health First Aid certified instruction and Smoke Free Public Space. She has experience in public speaking and presentations and has delivered multiple trainings for different entities such as Garfield Junior Police Academy, Bergen County Juvenile Officers Association, Bergen County Social Services, the faith based community in Passaic County, school nurses across Bergen County and countless schools throughout Bergen County. Delaney wants to run for council because she has seen her father, Councilman Delaney be involved in politics and has seen first hand what a difference he has made in the community. She said she wants to do the same and would love to have the opportunity to give back to the community that she grew up in. She said her and her father share similar goals including focusing on redevelopment, taxes, increasing community involvement and quality-of-life issues. "Community involvement is so important for people to feel invested," she said. She said she also wants to encourage residents to share their opinions and ideas. "It's important for residents to be heard. Their ideas do matter," Delaney said. "I want to work hand in hand with the community and open up a dialogue and open door with the council and residents." She said she also wants the open door to include the police department and residents and to have the community come together as a big family. Delaney said she wants to bring new events to the city and look into bringing back old events like the Boilermaker bonfires. She said she also wants to create ways to make community events more attainable to residents. She said some residents may not be able to attend due to childcare. She said she will look into ways to bring free childcare at events and break down any other barriers that prevent residents from getting involved. Delaney said running with her father has been wonderful. "He's my best friend and he knows my strengths and weaknesses and I know his," she said. "I think it will be great to bring that to the council. I think we make a great team and will be an even better team on the council." She also believes it's easier as well for a father and daughter to accept constructive criticism. "We don't always agree on the same thing, but we are able to work through it positively," Delaney said. Romi Herrera Romi Herrera has been a resident and homeowner in the City of Garfield for 11 years. As an active member of the community, Herrera has continuously demonstrated his commitment and dedication to improving the condition and well being of Garfield and its residents. Herrera is now up for a new challenge that would allow him to better represent the residents of Garfield on the city's council. Back in 2012, Herrera founded Garfield United, an organization aimed at empowering families through advocacy, resource management, and recreation. Since then, it has developed and expanded its reach to offer services to many of Garfield's residents and beyond. Through Herrera's leadership, the organization has successfully provided assistance with citizenship applications, naturalization classes, and speech workshops for those seeking legal status. Together with Garfield United, Herrera has also helped low income families fill out forms for their tax payments, advised residents about the process of property tax appeals and implemented recreational programs for children such as summer soccer camps and music lessons. Herrera also currently serves as an active member in the city's zoning board. In this role, Herrera has been keen to identify the issues that arise when residents and small business owners are barred from receiving the necessary permits and licenses to develop their businesses and properties. Herrera is determined to make more impactful change as a member of the Garfield City Council. He said he is dedicated to ensuring that Garfield's neighborhoods and school districts are safe for all children and residents. He and his wife, Elena, have three children, Solange, 22, Brittany, 21, and Peter, 9, who have gone through the city's public school system. If elected, he also wants to see the implementation of a volunteer safety unit that will help community policing and improve the relationship between local residents and police officers. He also wants to improve the quality of water and the infrastructure. Looking forward, Herrera envisions a more economically prosperous business district in Garfield. In order to achieve this goal, Herrera wants to improve the infrastructure of Garfield by proposing measures that would beautify the areas of commerce and make city officials more readily available to respond to the needs of small business owners. Herrera said he will work with the rest of the council to stabilize taxes and maintain an equitable tax system for all the residents of Garfield. Tony Lio Tony Lio is a lifelong resident of Garfield married to his wife, Dana. They have twin sons, Anthony and Dane. Both children are graduates of Garfield High School. Anthony is currently attending college and Dane is in the Bergen County Police Academy soon to be a police officer in Garfield. Lio is the owner/operator of a Garfield-based finance company offering corporate financing and leasing. He is a graduate of Garfield High School and attended Bergen Community College majoring in Business Administration. He has served as an agent for the Bergen County SPCA Law Enforcement Division, civically active with the children of the city coaching at the Boys & Girls Club, YMCA, Garfield Little League and the Garfield Jr. Boilermakers. He is presently a board trustee at the Boys & Girls Club of Garfield, a member of the Garfield UNICO and previously served on the Garfield Planning Board and is a former Vice President of the Garfield Board of Education. "As a lifelong resident of Garfield, I am unhappy with the current leadership that is running Garfield," he said. "I have asked myself; is Garfield a better place to live than it was 10-20 years ago? I think not. I am always listening to my friends and neighbors complain about issues within the city. It seems these important issues are always getting ignored or overlooked. Like crime, graffiti, public safety, absentee landlords, illegal apartments, sewer tax, street paving, quality of life issues, community re-development, attracting and maintaining businesses and supporting our schools." If elected, he has goals for the next four years. "We must work on bringing back respect, government transparency and a better quality of life to the residents of Garfield, restore confidence and trust in government, stabilize property taxes, increase programming and educational opportunities for our youth, support local businesses and enhance economic development in Garfield, improve Garfield's emergency services by updating equipment and facilities for police, fire and ambulance personnel," he said. "My running mate, Nikolce Milevski, and I will work hard and be a strong voice for the people and an advocate for the taxpayers." Lio would like to see the city a sound, healthy, united and growing city people would like to reside in during his term if elected. Glenn Mati Mati is finishing up his first term on the Garfield Council as the deputy mayor and has served on the Garfield Planning Board for the last four years. He is a retired Garfield Police Captain where he served for 34 years and is an active firefighter in the city for the last 43 years. He is currently employed as a safety officer with the Garfield Board of Education. In the past four years, he said the council's biggest accomplishment has been having a zero percent increase and actually reducing taxes. He said that was able to be accomplished by pushing redevelopment and getting businesses to help offset taxes for the residents. He said recently the city was able to build up the city's infrastructures by updating the roads, water and gas lines with Public Service. He said the city has also been able to acquire millions in grants to do things like upgrading 20th Century Field without taxing the residents. If re-elected, Mati said the next redevelopment priorities include Monroe Street and River Drive. He said developers are already interested in the areas. He said another major focus will be transforming Passaic Street into a Transit Village and upgrading the entire area. The dog park will also be built in the next couple of months at no cost to the taxpayer due to grants. He said the council has also been building up the police department. Mati said they next need to focus on building up the Department of Public Works to get more services to the residents faster. "Garfield to me is a hidden jewel," Mati said. "There are so many backgrounds in the city that all live together so well. With the development and new businesses the city is on the rise where other towns are struggling." "I believe in the last four years as a council we have all worked really hard together. We don't always agree but we do what's best for the city," Mati said. "We work well together and I'm proud of that. I believe we all deserve re-election for what we have accomplished in the last four years. We don't do it alone and we all earned it." Nikolce Milevski Milevski's family moved to Garfield in 1970 from Macedonia when he was just over a year old. He attended Garfield elementary schools and Elmwood Park High School. He then went to Ramapo State College and studied Business Administration. His wife lived in Garfield and went through the Garfield school district along with his two children. Milevski is currently the Vice Chair on the Garfield Planning Board and a member of the Garfield UNICO. He is also the President of the Macedonian Orthodox Cathedral in Cedar Grove and is the owner of the Firehouse Restaurant on Plauderville Avenue. He previously was a coach and mentor at the Garfield Little League, YMCA, Garfield Boys and Girls Club. "I still support and sponsor these organizations that do so much for our youth," he said. "While spending years on the Garfield planning board I feel it's my duty to help steer Garfield in a positive direction," he said. "Even though it's going to take time from my business and family, I know if good people don't get involved, Garfield will never become the great city it can be." If elected, he wants to improve quality of life issues, enforce laws against illegal apartments, restructure parking problems, make sure that the police department has the council's full support along with its citizens, and invite and entice new businesses to open locations in Garfield, and stop needless spending of tax dollars. He wants to spend the next fours years creating a well-informed city where all the citizens know about community events or when road construction projects or an emergency happen. Milevski said he wants to see the police department construction started and completed. He also wants to knock down condemned buildings and hold "slumlords landlords" accountable to properties they own in the city. He said he also wants to see the city work with the board of education more with shared services to save tax dollars and see redevelopment of the first ward. Tana Raymond Raymond was first elected to the city council in 2008. Raymond holds a bachelor of science degree in nursing, a master's in urban education and a master's in administration. She has a supervisor certification for public schools and an administrator's certificate. She is currently the supervisor of nurses in the Garfield School District and has served on many volunteer organizations and was part of the creation of the Garfield Animal Rescue Foundation. Raymond said one of her biggest accomplishments the past four years has been fighting illegal apartments in the city. She said more than $100,000 has been collected in illegal apartment fines. "It's so important to the city. If people have four families living in one house they need to pay taxes accordingly. It's stealing from the taxpayers," she said. "There are still a lot more to find." She said residents have been calling in tips every week and no one has accepted the $100 bounty. "That shows how much they care about the town," she said. Raymond said she has also tried to continue and carry on Councilman Delaney's redevelopment work. In October she has done four ribbon cuttings for new businesses. If re-elected, she has some of the same visions from the past four years like making the streets safer. She said she has met with some teenagers who hang on the streets and had good conversations. "I want to see them contributing. A lot of them have no support systems," Raymond said. "They really wanted a basketball court." Raymond said she suggested it to the council but it was met with resistance. She said if re-elected she will continue to pursue having a basketball court and creating more positive activities to help get their life back on track. "I always feel if I can save one child I've accomplished a mission," she said. She said she also wants continue the city's redevelopment plans while keeping Garfield affordable for the taxpayers. Last year, Garfield saw a decrease in the municipal taxes, which she said is important with hard working families in the city. Raymond also wants a K-9 unit for the police department. She said some of the police department's new hires have military backgrounds and have worked with K-9 units in the past. "I want to pursue avenues to make the addition to the police department. If we have our own K-9 unit it will save a lot of response time waiting for the county especially with school incidents," she said. She said she also wants to continue the Memorial Day parade and continue to honor veterans. In addition to the blue star program at the schools it creates an excellent source of collaboration between the city and veterans. "Working in the middle school has offered me the opportunity to have the city and board of education work together in shared service ventures," she said. "There is a good relationship now which was not always the case. We have developed a very good relationship and I truthfully believe working in the school district is an advantage." Raymond said the city is also in good financial standing with a AA- bond rating. "One of the most important factors in achieving that is the city manager and his conservative management of the city," she said. "There is more work to be done. I want to continue to serve and make the city a safer place for everyone to live I've lived in Garfield my whole life and have a lot invested," Raymond said. "I want people to know that if they came to Garfield and break the law they will get in trouble. I will try to address all these issues. The next big thing is the redevelopment of the first ward which is already in the works." Richard Rigoglioso Rigoglioso has served as the vice principal of Garfield Middle School for the last five years. He comes from a family of 10 and has lived in Garfield his entire life. He now has six children of his own who are the main reason why he is running for council. He said the town is changing and going in the wrong direction. "I take my kids to events in other towns but they are beginning to be more involved in the community with football and cheerleading," he said. Rigoglioso said he has worked in the school system for the last 20 years and sees things are changing and "not positively." "I think it's time for a different vision," he said. "The community needs to be more involved. If other towns can do it we can too if we reach out more." If elected, he said he would like to impose a term limit of three terms. "There are too many politicians stagnant and going through the motions. I think the council terms should be limited to 12 years," he said. "I know people vote you in, but after so many years there is so much power. After 12 years there should be some new fresh ideas. Right now if it's not their ideas. it's not a good idea." He believes that if there is a term limit the council will act more swiftly to get policies in motion and promote the growth of the city. Rigioglioso said he also sees a lot of redevelopment but that there are more anchor stores now. He said the city needs to focus on bringing in more "mom and pop" shops like in Ridgewood, Englewood and Montclair to attract outsiders into the town. He said there are many positive aspects to the city, like having two train stations, other forms of public transportation, being close to major highways, and minutes away from the Garden State Plaza and Hackensack University Medical Center. "We don't promote anything in a positive aspect. I think people should want to stop here and stay here. If people leave they don't talk about Garfield positively," he said. If elected, Rigoglioso said he wants to focus on promoting the superfund area in the city. "Chromium is the city's Achilles heel," he said. "The Environmental Protection Agency says the area is safe and they are planning to clean it, but what are we doing to promote the area?" He said people are renting out homes in the area and that people have redeveloped worse around the country. "I don't have the answers but I have a lot of questions that I'm willing to ask," he said. "People throw Garfield under the bus. People used to say it was a good blue collar town and it really bothers me and I'm passionate about it." Email: cattafi@northjersey.com NorthJersey.com : News : NJ State News : Elections in NJ NorthJersey.com : News : NJ State News : Elections in NJ November 8, 2016 Last updated: Tuesday, November 8, 2016, 1:54 PM Ten residents seek seats during Garfield's first November election By Kristie Cattafi Staff Writer |  Community News (Garfield Edition) Pages: 1 2 3 4 5 6 > display on one page Garfield will be holding it first November council election after the governing body approved to change the date this year. Ten residents are competing for five, four-year seats on Nov. 8. Incumbents Gaetana (Tana) Raymond, Glenn Mati, Louis Aloia, Joseph Delaney III and Franic Calandriello are seeking re-election along with residents Erin Delaney, Richard Rigoglioso, Romi Herrera, Nikolce Milevski and Tony Lio. Louis Aloia Aloia has served as mayor of Garfield from 1996 to 2000 and as a councilman from 2000 to present. He is married to his wife, Rosemarie, with six children and six grandchildren. He is the owner and manager of Aloia Funeral Home. Aloia said in the last four years he is most proud of the city's redevelopment including the General Pulaski statue at the new Garfield River Drive Park, Garden State Signature Place, Walmart, Applebees, McDonalds, and Wawa. He said he is also proud of the council for saving and maintaining the Garfield VFW. He said the VFW exemplifies community spirit and service. If re-elected Aloia wants to see future development of the city especially with the new police department and safety of town. He said he also wants to establish more fire vehicles and create a better public safety net for the city. Future redevelopment projects he wants to focus on is getting the Monroe Street complex developed. He said developing the Monroe Street area will be key because it will increase value in the first ward. He said the next four years will be focusing on developing the first ward and "making it equally blessed" like the rest of the city. He is a founding member of the Garfield Redevelopment Authority, is a former president of Garfield UNICO, was the director of the Garfield Chamber of Commerce for 10 years, is a former member of the Garfield Planning Board, housing authority and library board and the recipient of the Garfield Mayor's Award for outstanding civic contributions. Frank Calandriello Calandriello is running with Glenn Mati and Louis Aloia under the slogan "Working for you 2016." He has served on the council for 20 years, including three consecutive terms as mayor. He is the president of Frankie's Express Moving and F&M Leasing, a 55-year family owned business. He was inducted into the New Jersey State League of Municipalities in 2011 in the Mayoral Hall of Fame. He is been trustee of the Garfield Boys & Girls Club for the last 25 years, a Garfield Jr. Boilermaker coach for the last 20 years, and a coach for various sports for several years. He is also a founding member of the Garfield Redevelopment Authority, former chairman of the Garfield Housing Authority and former planning board member. Calandriello said he is very proud of his voting record. In 2016, the municipal tax was reduced. He said he felt the taxes were stabilized but a reduction is very "unique." He said the tax reduction was accomplished with the city's redevelopment efforts. Calandriello said he was a founding member of the redevelopment committee in 2001 where they successfully identified 54 acres. Since then, the redevelopment agency has brought in $5 million in developer fees to the city, including $2.8 million toward the new police station. The redevelopment has also brought new jobs to the city with the Passaic Street shopping center stores, Wawa and Price Rite. "During the recession across the state tax revenues dropped with tax appeals, but Garfield stayed steady with redevelopment," Calandriello said. "We still continue to do a great job bringing in new ratables and maintaining a healthy surplus." He said in the last four years the city also improved their bond rating to AA- and received millions in grants saving the taxpayers money. Something he is very proud of is holding the developer Vornado accountable for their "good faith commitment" of a property donation that is now being used for the dog park on Hobart Place. The grant money originally awarded for the dog park is now being used for River Drive's second phase of the river restoration project and being used to acquire land. "I have always supported smart development without compromising the quality of life for residents," he said. He said that is why he voted against using eminent domain in the first ward. "I'm in favor of redevelopment just not the eminent domain aspect," he said. "People have the right to stay in their homes or at least be compensated fairly." In the last four years, he has supported new protective lightening warning at 20th Century field, the General Pulaski statue and Garfield River Drive Park, hiring more police officers and getting more fire and safety vehicles, the VFW with refurbishing the building, library improvements, and the council of affordable housing program. Enter your valid email and access the PDF download. * ← Rare 1916 caused no stir when issued Gold Walker price $865? → ‘Gift’ not just a four-letter word Posted on November 8, 2016 by Dave Harper As far as the U.S. Mint is concerned, the holiday shopping season began yesterday. At least that is what I infer from my receipt of its Holiday Gift Guide in my email. As far as timing is concerned, the Mint is mainstream. I was in Wal-mart on Saturday morning and the cashier was wearing an elf cap. When I complimented her on it, she said she had just gotten it the day before. Of course, the Mint, Wal-mart and other retailers hope we all will spend, spend, spend. The Mint’s gift guide prominently features the two 2016 commemorative coin series. If you know someone who is fond of the works of Mark Twain, a gold $5 or silver dollar honoring the classic American author just might be the perfect present. A lover of the great outdoors might be a prime candidate for one of the coins celebrating the 100th anniversary of the National Park Service. There is a $5 gold piece, a silver dollar and a clad half dollar. If you consider both the proof and uncirculated versions, you have six coins to choose from. Gifts are probably the last hope for either commemorative program to move the sales numbers much higher. Collectors have had most of the year to make up their minds. If they have not purchased them by now, the only added inducement might come in December when a last look at sales numbers might reveal one that is extremely low – implying future profits if you buy it. For something current, the Mint’s catalog takes the viewer to a page on which appears the uncirculated mintmarked silver American Eagle celebrating the 30th anniversary of the program. It has a lettered edge rather than the standard reeding as appears on the regular issue 2016 bullion silver Eagle. But it will not be available until Dec. 1. That should be no problem as in recent years the Mint has excelled in swift delivery times. For me this year, the best part of the gift guide is the portion devoted to medals. Medals do not get enough attention. I am as guilty as the next collector at relegating them to second class status compared to coins. The old Life cereal commercial seems an appropriate mention here. Everybody in it wanted to let Mikey try the new cereal first. Well, with medals, a gift of a medal to Mikey might just lead to greater numbers of collectors if he likes it. The medals offered have attractive artwork and honor incredible people, from veterans to Mother Teresa. This entry was posted in Buzz. Bookmark the permalink. ← Rare 1916 caused no stir when issued Gold Walker price $865? → Leave a Reply Cancel reply You must be logged in to post a comment. There a very few muzzle-loading Pennsylvania, Kentucky, home or civilian rifles that were left-handed. The Cumberland Gap quarter shows ... Register today to submit a letter to the editor! Environmental Leader Columns News Videos Jobs Research Webinars Conference 2017   X Webinar: Are you still in compliance? Learn how EPA Clean Air Act changes affect your organization November 16, 2016, 2 PM ET Sponsored by Sphera Register Now>> Popular ENERGY EFFICIENCY EMISSIONS CARBON FINANCE FACILITIES SUPPLY CHAIN SUSTAINABILITY WATER SMART GRID More Topics »Close » Sustainable Strategies & Leadership Contracts & Installations Green Fleets & Transportation Funding & Incentives Sustainability Reports Government Environmental Design Hi-Tech Pollution Climate Ecolabels & Certifications Waste & Recycling Carbon Finance & Offsets Construction & Refitting Green Marketing Sustainable Manufacturing Green Research Energy Efficient Lighting Solar Energy Environmental Policy & Law Products & Planning Finance & Reporting Sustainable Packaging & Paper Conventional Energy Baseline Clean Energy Green Workplace Efficiency Environmental Conservation Utilities ALL TOPICS   Home » All EL Stories » Walmart Wants to Set a Global Example and Vows to Represent all Stakeholders November 8, 2016 Walmart Wants to Set a Global Example and Vows to Represent all StakeholdersBy: Ken Silverstein Related Stories Mars Drinks’ Single Serve Packaging Redesign Cuts Carbon Footprint by 31% Alcatraz Cruises Launches Hybrid Ferryboat Walmart to Save $150m with Sustainability Initiatives in FY13 Walmart Foundation, Target, US Chamber Foundation to Launch Circular Economy Pilot Keurig Transitioning to Recylable K-Cups Related Topics All EL Stories Circular Economy Clean Energy Climate Feature Products & Planning Recycling Solar Energy Sustainable Strategy & Leadership Waste & Recycling Waste Management Wind Energy Walmart is a leading employer. And it’s also a leader in the area of sustainability. It just announced a new plan to achieve science-based targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions that conform to the standards set by the Paris climate accords. Among other things, Walmart is doubling sales of locally grown produce in the U.S. and expanding and enhancing sustainable sourcing to cover 20 key commodities, including bananas, coffee and tea. The company’s announcement came in Philadelphia last Friday at its Net Impact Conference, all with a goal of increasing “trust and transparency.”  “We want to make sure Walmart is a company that our associates and customers are proud of – and that we are always doing right by them and by the communities they live in,” says Doug McMillon, chief executive of WalMart, at the conference. “That’s really what these commitments are about. And that’s why we’re so passionate about them.” It is sourcing more energy from renewables and has dedicated itself to paying its associates more. It says it is dedicated to doing the right thing, and giving people more access to more products. It says it wants to redefine what it means to do good. Walmart is the first retailer with an emissions-reduction plan approved by the Science Based Targets Initiative, in alignment with the Paris Climate Agreement in December 2015, the company says. Under the approved plan, Walmart will use a combination of energy-efficiency measures and renewable energy to achieve an 18 percent emissions reduction in its own operations by 2025. Additionally, Walmart will work with suppliers to reduce emissions by 1 Gigaton by 2030, equivalent to taking more than 211 million passenger vehicles off of U.S. roads and highways for a year. Is this the WalMart that you know? McMillion asked attendees. He says WalMart is a quite a different company from what people have perceived it to be. While the company felt it had good people doing good work, Hurricane Katrina caused it to reach an epiphany. It resolved itself to throw its people, merchandise and money to solving that specific problem. But it changed the company, he said. How can we be this company all the time? he asked, thus committing itself to such a standard, always. He said that WalMart listened to its critics, who were concerned about its environmental and labor practices. Walmart has a platform. And so it chose to set three goals and to improve in the following areas: achieving zero waste, increasing renewable energy  and selling increasingly sustainable products over time in sustainable packaging. The company set them in aspirational ways and since 2005, it has been on its way to chipping away at these aims. It is serving all stakeholders, McMillion says. On Friday, it set new objectives: Building on those sustainability goals it set in 2005, it shoots further —  to create zero waste in company operations, to operate with 100% renewable energy — 50% by 2025 — and to sell products that sustain natural resources and the environment. “Those aspirational goals have guided how Walmart engages on those vital issues and progress has been made toward them. The new roadmap builds on progress to date, but also broadens the company’s vision of its role in society.” The record so far? In 2015, 25 percent of Walmart’s operations were powered by renewable energy, a significant step towards the 2005 goal. Going forward, the company says that it will source half of its energy needs from renewable sources by 2025, as part of a plan designed to achieve science-based targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. In 2015, 75 percent of Walmart’s global waste was diverted from landfills, the company says, helping to reduce costs to the business, customers and society. Under the roadmap, the company will achieve zero waste to landfill from our own operations in key markets, including the U.S., U.K., Japan, and Canada by 2025, it continues. The commitment is designed to meet or exceed EPA zero waste guidelines.  McMillon also discussed WalMart’s $2.7 billion investment in its employees — money that has been targeted to education, wages and training. On average, a store manager makes $175,000 a year. It will hire for talent and train for skill, he noted, saying that his first job was unloading trucks at WalMart — and that he rear-ended his boss’ car the first day on his job. “Today we are asking other retailers to join us in helping people live better,” he says. “Let’s use our collective power to create good jobs with good training that become good careers for all our associates … People will have a better shot of taking advantage of the opportunities in front of them.”  Mars Drinks’ Single Serve Packaging Redesign Cuts Carbon Footprint by 31% Alcatraz Cruises Launches Hybrid Ferryboat Walmart to Save $150m with Sustainability Initiatives in FY13 Walmart Foundation, Target, US Chamber Foundation to Launch Circular Economy Pilot Keurig Transitioning to Recylable K-Cups Reader Comments There are no comments for this story.   Name (required) Mail (will not be published) (required) Website Energy Manager News ERC Price Benchmark Trends Week Ending: November 4, 2016 The Evolution of Whole Building Interval Data Updated Standard from ANSI, ASHRAE and IES Wyoming Refining to Save with New Motors, LEDs Washington State Rejects Nation’s First Carbon Tax at the Polls Where’s Oil Headed? Companies moving from traditional on-premise, perpetually-licensed EHS software to technology services that are cloud-based, subscription service-based offerings has become a macro trend. When it’s time to look for a new software solution, the temptation is great to use the technical buzz phrases that get tossed around frequently. Back to Reading News Metro Page Six Sports Business Opinion Entertainment Fashion Living Media Tech Real Estate Sub Menu 1 Photos Video Covers Columnists Horoscopes Sub Menu 2 Classifieds Subscribe Sign in In The News: hillary clinton iran lamar odom 2016 presidential election new york mets Sections Search Tips Sign in New York Post Most Popular 54,340 Sanders says it's not Comey's fault that Clinton lost 43,222 'I came here to kill you': Cop-killer stalked family for days 29,971 Read John Lennon's harsh words for Paul McCartney 27,847 The one scenario that could still get Hillary into the White House 25,666 Dead rodent sewn into woman's new Zara dress: lawsuit 22,354 Melania Trump's girl-on-girl photos from racy shoot revealed Share this: Facebook Twitter Google WhatsApp Email Copy Business Share this: Facebook Twitter Google WhatsApp Email Copy Seasonal retail jobs taking a hit this holiday season By Lisa Fickenscher View author archive Get author RSS feed Name(required) Email(required) Comment(required) November 8, 2016 | 1:31am Modal Trigger Photo: AP More On: holiday shopping This is the best day of the year to do your holiday shopping Under Armour goes over the top with $1,500 trench coat Mall of America takes a stand against shopping on Thanksgiving Walmart facing uphill battle just to survive Good luck finding help at some of the country’s largest retailers during the holidays. As shopping season kicks into high gear, most retailers are cutting back on sales help in their stores, a survey of hiring announcements reveals. Walmart, which last year proudly announced that it was hiring 60,000 extra workers for the holiday shopping season, this year is staying uncharacteristically silent on its plans. “We don’t yet have a number to share, mainly because we are looking at seasonal hiring on a much more local, store-by-store basis this year,” a Walmart spokesperson told The Post. Retailers typically advertise for seasonal help in September and hire in October. The giant discounter’s plan includes giving current workers “access to extra hours,” the spokesperson said. Walmart said earlier this year that it would use existing employees as “Santa’s helpers,” giving them a yellow vest and a Santa hat. CareerTrends | Graphiq At Toys R Us, executives are not disclosing the number of temporary workers the chain will hire. Last year, it announced that it would hire 40,000 workers. “With an expected growth in online shopping,” said a Toys R Us spokeswoman, “we’ve placed a greater focus on hiring for our e-commerce fulfillment centers as well as back-of-house operations at our stores.” Retail employment in October fell 21 percent, to 154,600, from a year ago, or the steepest such decline in five years, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas. “The numbers coming out from the Labor Department show that most retailers have announced hiring plans that are flat to down from last year,” said Chief Executive Officer John Challenger. Nordstrom and Macy’s are trimming their ranks by small percentages — 3 percent and 2 percent, respectively — while GameStop is reducing the number of people it hires in its stores, a spokeswoman said. To be sure, some retailers are adding about the same number of part-time workers as last year, including Target and Kohl’s. Meanwhile, highlighting the phenomenal growth of online sales, Amazon said it is hiring 120,000 extra workers — 20 percent more than last year. “The megatrend here is that as more shopping migrates online, the fewer people retailers need in their stores,” said Craig Johnson, president of Customer Growth Partners. Indeed, Target is adding 7,500 workers to its fulfillment and distribution centers, or 1,000 more than last year, “because our online sales are increasing,” said a spokeswoman. Business News Home > Business > Business News < Back to SMG 45 Tuesday, 8 November 2016 | MYT 9:43 AM Breakfast briefing: Tuesday, November 8 MarketWrap: Wall Street surged on the eve of the US presidential election, with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton's prospects brightening after the FBI said it would not press criminal charges against her over the use of a private email server. US stocks on Monday racked up their biggest one-day percentage gain since March 1, while a volatility measure recorded its biggest drop since late June. - Reuters The DJIA jumped 2.08% to end at 18,259.67 points and the S&P 500 surged 2.22% to 2,131.52 and the Nasdaq added 2.37% to 5,166.17. Forex summary *The ringgit gained 0.02% to 4.2120 per US$ *It was 0.11% higher at 4.6478 per euro *Down 0.08% to 5.2205 per pound sterling *Up 0.03% to 3.0266 per Singapore dollar *0.38% lower to 3.2449 per Aussie *Up 0.03% to 4.0306 per 100 yen Energy Oil prices were stable early on Tuesday after posting strong gains the previous day, with investors piling money into financial markets in expectation that Democrat Hillary Clinton would win the US presidential election. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures were down 1 cent at US$44.88 per barrel at 0038 GMT. - Reuters Top foreign stories US banks gird for Brexit-style tumult following Tuesday's election: US banks, including Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase & Co and Goldman Sachs Group Inc, are bracing for potential tumult on financial markets in the wake of Tuesday's US election. Traders expect US stock prices to swing by about 2% in either direction on Wednesday, the day after the election, based on the price of S&P 500 index options. - Reuters News Corp posts quarterly loss as print ad sales fall: News Corp, the owner of the Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones Newswires and book publisher HarperCollins, reported a quarterly loss as it struggles to cope with a decline in newspaper advertising sales. News Corp's net loss attributable to shareholders was US$15 million, or 3 cents per share, compared with a profit of US$175 million, or 30 cents per share, a year earlier. - Reuters Wal-Mart Pay in talks with several mobile wallet companies: Wal-Mart Stores Inc is in talks with several mobile wallet companies to offer more payment options in its Wal-Mart Pay app, an executive at the world's largest retailer said, after signing up JPMorgan Chase & Co last week. Starting next year, Chase Pay will become the first third-party digital wallet on Wal-Mart's website and app. - Reuters Russia signs decree to sell 19.5% Rosneft stake: Russia published a government decree on Monday ordering the sale of a 19.5% stake in state-controlled oil giant Rosneft in time for the proceeds to be received by the end of the year. - Reuters Top local stories Currencies under pressure: Emerging market currencies came under pressure just two days before the majority of Americans cast their votes in the US presidential election. Most emerging market currencies were trending lower against US dollar, with the ringgit slumping near its lowest point in months on the back of a renewed strengthening of the US dollar. - StarBiz Axiata to buy 12.5% more in edotco Myanmar: Axiata Group Bhd proposes to exercise a call option for the acquisition of an additional 12.5% stake in edotco Myanmar Ltd in a deal valued at US$35mil (RM147.4mil). - StarBiz Reach to hold deferred EGM on Nov 16: Special-purpose acquisition company Reach Energy Bhd, which is seeking to secure shareholder approval for its maiden acquisition, has set Nov 16 as the new date for its deferred EGM. - StarBiz S&P affirms Malaysia’s sovereign ratings: Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services (S&P) has affirmed Malaysia’s sovereign ratings with a stable outlook based on the country’s strong external position and high monetary flexibility with its relatively weaker but stable public finances. The rating agency said Malaysia’s foreign-currency sovereign credit ratings at A- for the long-term and A-2 for the short-term papers has been maintained while the local-currency sovereign credit ratings would be maintained at A for the long-term and A-1 for the short-term papers. - StarBiz Sunway proposes JV to tap digital media: Sunway Bhd unit Sunway Holdings Sdn Bhd has inked an agreement with three parties to collaborate as partners to invest in digital media business content and assets. - StarBiz AirAsia, AirAsia X staff move into new corporate base: AirAsia and AirAsia X staff moved into its new corporate base called RedQ, located beside KLIA2 on Monday. RedQ, short for RedQuarters, covers an area of 18,000 sq m and will house up to 2,000 AirAsia Allstars, the name the budget carriers’ employees are known as. - StarBiz Analysts laud Star Media’s move into VoD services: Star Media Group Bhd’s venture into video-on-demand (VoD) services is a bold move for the group as it diversifies its business model to the digital entertainment space to complement its traditional print business, analysts say. The strategy to launch dimsum to enter the entertainment space through over-the-top technology was a good entry point into video broadcasting as it was an asset-light model, they say. - StarBiz Scicom profit jumps 24%: Scicom (MSC) Bhd posted a 23.71% jump in net profit to RM12mil for its first quarter mainly due to an increase in billings for outsourcing projects in line with positive industry projections. Revenue rose 16.29% to RM52.1mil. - StarBiz Bank Negara reserves unchanged at US$97.8b: Bank Negara’s international reserves were unchanged in US dollar terms at US$97.8bil as at Oct 31. However, in ringgit terms, the reserves dipped to RM405.5bil from RM405.6bil as at Oct 14. - StarBiz RSPO in a spot again over IOI Corp case: The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) has found itself in a difficult position again over the suspension and reinstatement of the certification of sustainable palm oil for IOI Corp Bhd.  This time, a non-governmental organisation is unhappy and threatening to quit the self-regulating body established to promote the growth and use of certified sustainable palm oil. - Edge FD Shareholders advised to accept Taisei’s RM1 revised offer for Maypak: Mercury Securities Sdn Bhd, the independent adviser for the takeover offer for 54.95% of Malaysia Packaging Industry Bhd (Maypak) by Taisei Lamick Co Ltd, has recommended that shareholders accept the revised offer of RM1, although it deemed the offer not fair. - Edge FD New Hoong Fatt 3Q net profit up 22%, pays three sen dividend: New Hoong Fatt Holdings Bhd net profit jumped 22.4% to RM6.41 million for the third quarter, on fair value gain on its investment properties amounting to RM900,000 recognised during the period. Revenue rose 2.5% to RM54.48 million, mainly due to higher demand in the local market. - Edge FD Tags / Keywords: Breakfast Briefing You May Be Interested Concern about IOI Prop’s Singapore deal Daibochi to invest RM29mil in Myanmar JV company Weak ringgit to impact 5 sectors Where are you on the journey to financial freedom? CV Rep opens new Producer's Club at theatre location Darby Wright , TDS 4:54 p.m. PST November 7, 2016 Your Business Your News CVRep Board Chair Gary D. Hall and Founding Artistic Director Ron Celona share the honors of cutting the ribbon on the new Producers Club. Also shown are (L-R): CVRep VP of Development Andrea Spirtos, CFRE; CVRep Board Member David Cohan; CVRep Development Director Barbara Wolser; from the City of Cathedral City, Councilmember Shelley Kaplan, Mayor Stan Henry, Councilmember Mark Carnevale; and CVRep Board Secretary Scott Sherman. (Photo: Submitted photo) Openings, innovations & renovations Coachella Valley Repertory (CVRep) recently held a ribbon cutting ceremony and open house for their new Producer’s Club at their Rancho Mirage Theatre. On hand for the October 24th ceremony were Cathedral City Mayor Stan Henry, Mayor Pro-Tem Greg Pettis, and Council-members Shelley Kaplan and Mark Carnevale; members of both the Palm Desert and Cathedral City Chambers of Commerce, and several longtime supporters of CVRep including Linda Rider, Gerald Green and Vern Kozlen. Members of the CVRep Producers Club can use the room prior to and at intermissions at their performances, plus attend special dinners and afternoon teas. Atma Wiseman Interiors designed the Producers Club for CVRep. Wiseman is a member of the CVRep Board of Directors. For more information on the CVRep Producers Club (760) 296-2966 or email info@cvrep.org. Previous: CVRep story on future Cathedral City theater purchase Walmart opened its first training academy in California on November 1 at the Walmart Supercenter located at 79295 Highway 111 in La Quinta. Academies are a dedicated facility located in, or adjacent to, a Walmart Supercenter where hourly supervisors and department managers will receive two weeks of hands-on training that combines both the classroom and the sales floor. Walmart has created a new end-to-end training program called Pathways for associates at all levels of store operations, from entry-level to Regional General Manager. Hourly frontline supervisors and department managers will attend a dedicated two-week training program at the academy facility as part of Pathways. Braille Institute Rancho Mirage announced that it will unveil its newly updated and remodeled teaching kitchen in a special community ceremony on 10 a.m. November 10. The fully remodeled kitchen features both gas and electric stovetops, typical kitchen storage and sinks, and other appliances that the average person has in their own kitchen. To help students regain confidence in the kitchen, the Braille Institute Rancho Mirage Kitchen Confidence instructors highlight topics such as safely pouring hot liquids, kitchen organization and food safety, lighting suggestions, and how to identify, mark and label foods. In addition, students get hands-on experience applying the new skills to meal preparation. Kitchen Confidence class instructors’ offer free programming in English and Spanish to any Coachella Valley resident who experiences vision loss. The instructors combine general kitchen safety lessons with creative tips to adapt traditional cooking techniques. The relaunched Kitchen Confidence program is available year-round. Although there is no fee to participate, students must register with Braille Institute by calling (760) 321-1111 or by visiting the center located at 70251 Ramon Road in Rancho Mirage. CV Link, has been recommended to receive $24.3 million in active transportation funding from the State of California, officials have announced. This is the largest single award announced for the valley’s multi-modal transportation corridor, and it ensures that the project’s construction can be funded from Palm Springs to Coachella. The grant was recommended to be funded by the California Transportation Commission (CTC) staff, which identified 50 projects statewide that should receive $158 million from the 2017 Active Transportation Program. CV Link received 89.5 points and topped the statewide list in terms of the amount of funding allocated. The CTC staff recommendations will be presented to the California Transportation Commission for approval in December. Previous story and video interviews on CV Link funding Philanthropy Desert Healthcare District, a local government agency that provides health-related community grants, recently approved funding to LifeStream Prostate Cancer Treatment Program to purchase new advanced cellular collection technology. The grant will allow LifeStream to expand its “autologous cellular immunotherapy” program, an FDA-approved treatment regimen proven to prolong the lives of prostate cancer patients. The apheresis machine, Optia, collects mononuclear cellular products from men with advanced forms of prostate cancer, which are then processed and transformed into cancer-fighting cells that are returned to the patient. Optia uses the patient’s own immune cells and reprograms them to attack existing cancer cells. This treatment is proven to prolong the lives of these men. Recognition Designed to rate how well hospitals protect patients from accidents, errors, injuries and infections, the latest Hospital Safety Score honored Eisenhower Medical Center, in Rancho Mirage with an “A,” the top grade in patient safety. The Hospital Safety Score is compiled under the guidance of the nation’s leading experts on patient safety and is administered by The Leapfrog Group (Leapfrog), an independent industry watchdog. The Hospital Safety Score is fully transparent, offering a full analysis of the data and methodology used in determining grades on the website. Patients can also review their hospital’s past safety performance alongside its current grade on the Hospital Safety Score site.To see Eisenhower Medical Center’s full score, and to access safety tips for patients and their loved ones, visit the Hospital Safety Score website at www.hospitalsafetyscore.org. Previous story: Loma Linda Children's Hospital groundbreaking in Indio Darby Wright  (Photo: Desert Sun) Submit your business announcement to Darby.Wright@DesertSun.com CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE Read or Share this story: http://desert.sn/2fxJUeD TOP VIDEOS Donald Trump’s victory sends U.S. dollar soaring 2:24 Bill Cosby: Hopes of resuming illustrious career 0:26 Closing Bell: Emerging markets decline on Trump Win 1:08 Procter & Gamble merges beauty business with Coty 3:19 Gadget Makers Target Health At CES Unveiled 1:41 Chinese spend billions on singles day 0:55 McDonald's Workers Share Birthday and Last Name 1:44 Try out Google's Daydream View 1:47 UAW President would welcome meeting with Trump 0:46 Chinese company launches Single's Day shopping festival 0:48 More Stories Eagles of Death Metal manager says members weren't denied entry at Paris theater Nov. 14, 2016, 11:02 a.m. Largest shuffleboard club in California resumes play Nov. 14, 2016, 10:27 a.m. How Genetic Testing Could Save You from Your Family Nov. 14, 2016, 3:20 p.m.

PC-Tablet Videos Tech Apps Telecom Science Business Social Auto Reviews How-To’s Featured Black Friday Deals: Walmart, Amazon, Sam’s Club offers on iPhones and iPads By Anand Narayanaswamy - 10/11/2016 Black Friday falls on November 25. US-based retail giants Walmart and Sam’s Club have launched special deals as part of the upcoming Black Friday. According to sources, Apple products will be provided with big discounts with free gift cards. Recently, Sam’s Club had published a 12-page advertisement regarding Black Friday 2016 deals. The retailer has featured crazy iPad and iPhone deals in “Sam’s Club Lowest Prices of the Season” ad. Black Friday great discounts for iPhone 7 on November 22 You can expect to get great discounts on iPhone 7 at the special sale event on November 22. According to analysts, potential customers should not miss the discount. The retailer has featured the best deal on the flagship Apple iPad Pro 9.7. You will be able to save $175 on the iPad Pro during the special November 12 sale at Sam’s Club. Even though the Wi-Fi and smartphone models are part of the deal, the 32GB has been excluded from the discounts. Sams Club is offering discounts for iPhone on November 12. Black Friday purchase gives you free $250 gift card with each order You can also expect great deals on the newly launched iPhone 7, iPhone 7 Plus, and iPhone SE. Moreover, you will be eligible to get a free $250 gift card from the retailer if you purchase on November 12. You can use the value of the card for additional purchases on Black Friday. Sam’s Club Black Friday deals only available offline You should note that the Black Friday 2016 deals on iPhones are only available in Sam’s Club stores and will not be available online. Hence, you need a physical presence at the store location. You can expect more great deals on November 22. However, we don’t have any confirmation about the level of discounts. If you would like to buy online, you need to wait till 12.01 AM on November 24 since the Sam’s Club Black Friday 2016 sale kicks off from that date. The physical stores will open on November 25, 7AM. Black Friday deals offered by Walmart You can buy a 16GB variant of iPhone 6 for $399, which is a huge discount from the original $549. You can buy a Silver color variant of Apple iPhone 6 Plus for $499 instead of $749. The 8GB iPhone 5c AT&T-locked model is available for $229. If you would like to buy Sprint-locked model, it will be on sale for $239. Meanwhile, e-commerce giant Amazon has also launched an exclusive Black Friday Deals Store, which features cloths, computers, electronics, toys, games, sports and other related products at steep discounts. You will be able to find new deals every day until December 22. Amazon also offers products under upcoming deals that feature select items available only for members of Amazon Prime program. We also expect Amazon to introduce exclusive Black Friday deals from November 21 to 25.  Walmart sued for selling fake 'Egyptian cotton' sheets Jonathan Stempel, Reuters Nov. 9, 2016, 12:26 PM 1,606 facebook linkedin twitter email print Thomson Reuters Wal-Mart Stores Inc was sued on Tuesday on behalf of consumers who said the world's largest retailer sold products falsely labeled "100 % Egyptian Cotton" from an Indian textile company for many years after it first became suspicious of their origin. According to the complaint, Wal-Mart questioned the fiber content of Welspun India Ltd's <WLSP.NS> products as early as 2008, but waited until two months ago to halt sales of its mislabeled Egyptian cotton bed linens, following a similar halt by Target Corp <TGT.N>. The plaintiff, Dorothy Monahan of Michigan, said she overpaid at a Wal-Mart for Better Homes and Gardens bed linens made by Welspun that she thought were made of Egyptian cotton, and therefore higher quality than cheaper bed linens. She accused Wal-Mart of violating U.S. laws governing textile fiber labeling and advertising, and is seeking damages for everyone who has bought bed linens at Wal-Mart made by Welspun and labeled "100% Egyptian Cotton." "We plan to vigorously defend the company," a Wal-Mart spokesman said. He said the retailer removed such products after conducting a comprehensive review nearly two months ago and since then has offered customers a full refund. A lawyer for Monahan did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Monahan is represented by the law firm Hagens Berman Sobol Shapiro, whose specialties include product liability. Her complaint was filed with the U.S. District Court in Manhattan. Egyptian cotton typically commands premiums from shoppers because its long cotton fibers contribute to a finer, lighter, softer and more durable fabric. Although the United States and Australia produce more high-end cotton, the Egyptian product has retained its prestige because of the northeast African country's long history of growing it. Wal-Mart has also sold Welspun bed linen under the "Canopy" name, and in September called "unacceptable" the Indian company's inability to assure that its products were 100 percent Egyptian cotton. The Bentonville, Arkansas-based retailer nonetheless decided to work with Welspun to improve quality control and labeling, rather than cut ties. Other U.S. retailers, including Bed Bath & Beyond Inc <BBBY.O> and J.C. Penney Co <JCP.N>, also began reviewing their ties to Welspun after Target's announcement. The case is Monahan v Wal-Mart Stores Inc, U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York, No. 16-08662. (Reporting by Jonathan Stempel in Washington, D.C.,; Editing by Andrew Hay and Dan Grebler) Read the original article on Reuters. Copyright 2016. Follow Reuters on Twitter. Kent County sheriff's detectives on Wednesday, Nov. 9 released a surveillance video that showed the men at a Grand Rapids area Walmart store. Police say one man acts as a lookout while the other sneaks into a restricted area to access registers in an apparent administrative area. Surveillance video captured the theft and the two men leaving a Walmart store. In a Facebook post, police noted that stores on 28th Street SE and in Comstock Park had been targeted. Anyone with information about the men can call Silent Observer at 616-774-2345 or message the sheriff's department through its Facebook page. AccuWeather.com Quick Look Change your current location » View Full Weather Report Search Search Search Cleveland.com Account Sign In Close Sign in to Cleveland.com You are signed in as Edit Public Profile Sign Out Subscribe The Plain Dealer Sun News Media Insider Rewards comments Woman says man was masturbating when he sought directions from her: Mayfield Village Police Blotter Print Email Andy Attina / cleveland.com By Andy Attina / cleveland.com Sun News on November 09, 2016 at 4:13 PM, updated November 09, 2016 at 4:14 PM comments MAYFIELD VILLAGE, Ohio Public indecency, SOM Center Road: A woman, 45, said a man drove his vehicle alongside her while she was walking her dog Nov. 1 and asked for directions to Walmart. As she approached his vehicle to give him directions, she said she noticed he was masturbating. As she walked away and called police, the Hiram man, 27, followed her until officers arrived and arrested him for public indecency. Theft, Wilson Mills Road: A student at Mayfield High School reported Nov. 1 that over the previous two school days someone had stolen $182 in cash from her locked locker. School officials are reviewing surveillance video in an effort to identify a suspect. Body found, SOM Center Road: A woman reported at 6:30 a.m. Nov. 2 she pried up a bedroom door to a room where a man was staying and found him face down and not breathing. Responding officers and paramedics confirmed the Richmond Heights man, 39, was dead. There was evidence of drug abuse found in the room. The woman said he had a drug history and was staying with her while he was in rehab. The drug enforcement unit is investigating. Harassing communication, Wilson Mills Road: Officers responded to a doctor's office Nov. 2 for a report of a patient who was making harassing phone calls since he had been dismissed from the practice and refused treatment. While they were taking the report, the South Euclid man, 41, called the office eight times. Officers told him to stop calling and he said he would comply. Departmental information, Wilson Mills Road: A Mayfield High School teacher said Nov. 3 she received a phone call from a parent of a student the previous day. The parent was upset because she reported an incident to child and family services, which was now investigating it. Harassing communication, Aintree Park Drive: A woman reported Nov. 3 her ex-husband confronted her at her home and continues to harass her through phone calls and text messages. The man reported Nov. 7 the woman is also harassing him. The incident is under review by the prosecutor. Unauthorized use of a motor vehicle, Beta Drive: A Progressive Insurance employee reported Nov. 4 a customer refused to return a loaner car and the company had not since been able to get in touch with him. Officers also tried to contact him, but could not. A warrant was issued for the arrest of the 25-year-old Cleveland man. Suspicious activity, Aintree Park Drive: A woman called 911 around 1 a.m. Nov. 7 and said she was awakened by someone knocking on her door and what sounded like her door being opened with a key. She stayed in her bedroom and did not go to the door. Responding officers discovered the woman had left her keys in the door and they believed someone may have been trying to let her know. Everything checked OK in the home. See more Mayfield Village news at Cleveland.com/hillcrest. If you would like to discuss the police blotter, please visit our crime and courts comments page. AccuWeather.com Quick Look Change your current location » View Full Weather Report Search Search Search NJ.com Account Sign In Close Sign in to NJ.com You are signed in as Edit Public Profile Sign Out Subscribe Email newsletters The Star-Ledger The Times of Trenton The Jersey Journal South Jersey Times Hunterdon County Democrat Star Gazette comments Court appearance for driver in Tracy Morgan crash rescheduled Print Email Alex Napoliello | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com By Alex Napoliello | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com The Star-Ledger Email the author | Follow on Twitter on November 09, 2016 at 2:25 PM, updated November 09, 2016 at 4:32 PM comments NEW BRUNSWICK — The former Wal-Mart truck driver accused of causing the June 2014 crash that injured comedian Tracy Morgan and killed another man appeared briefly in Middlesex County Superior Court Wednesday afternoon. Kevin Roper, 37, of Jonesboro, Ga., made the trip up north to New Brunswick only to find out during his less than five minute appearance that the hearing would be rescheduled for Nov. 29. Roper's attorney, David Jay Glassman, and Middlesex County Assistant Prosecutor Sheree Pitchford met behind closed doors with Judge Michael Toto for approximately 10 minutes. When they emerged, Toto asked the two parties to return at a later date. Glassman declined to comment outside the courtroom. Roper was driving a Wal-Mart tractor-trailer on the New Jersey Turnpike near Exit 8A in Cranbury when he crashed into a limo bus carrying Morgan and others. Fellow comedian James "Jimmy Mack" McNair, who was riding in the limo bus with Morgan, died in the crash. The National Transportation Safety Board determined driver fatigue caused the collision. Roper, who had not slept for more than 28 hours, was driving 20 miles an hour over the posted 45 mph speed limit in a construction work zone before the collision, which set off a chain reaction that involved six vehicles and 21 people, authorities have said. "The driver, already going too fast, was slow to react," NTSB Chair Christopher Hart said. A month after the NTSB report, Glassman asked a Superior Court judge to drop the charges of assault by auto and death by auto, because he didn't feel his client would get a fair trial. Glassman, in court filings, contended Roper would not be able to get an "impartial jury" due to extensive media coverage, civil settlements in the case and the NTSP report. A former star on "Saturday Night Live" and "30 Rock," Morgan suffered a traumatic brain injury and broken bones in the crash. He settled a lawsuit against Wal-Mart for an undisclosed amount in May 2015. Wal-Mart reached a $10 million settlement with McNair's two children in January 2015. Roper has pleaded not guilty to aggravated manslaughter, vehicular homicide and eight counts of aggravated assault. Morgan has since returned to performing, making a guest appearance on SNL and embarking on the "Picking up the Pieces" tour. In April, the tour came to the State Theatre in New Brunswick, approximately 15 miles north from where the crash occurred.   Alex Napoliello may be reached at anapoliello@njadvancemedia.com. Follow him on Twitter @alexnapoNJ. Find NJ.com on Facebook.
