Skip to main content Labs Blog Mobile About Us Help Login / Register Home Updates Countries Disasters Topics Organizations Jobs Training 08 Nov 2016 Economic Strengthening Officer- 1 Vacancy based in Lira (Open to Ugandan Nationals Only) Jobfrom Mercy Corps — Closing date: 17 Nov 2016 PROGRAM/DEPARTMENT SUMMARY: Mercy Corps has been operating in Uganda since 2006 and works to catalyse change makers within the Ugandan private sector, civil society and government to create economically dynamic, healthy and secure communities. Our works focus on building resilience and enable economic growth, improve opportunities to attain better health and nutrition, and improved governance and conflict management. We implement programs in northern Uganda Acholi and Karamoja regions with funding from USAID, USDA, Walmart Foundation, SDC, DFID as well as other private donations. Mercy Corps is looking for a qualified candidate to fill the position of Economic Strengthening Officer based in Lira for the USAID funded five years program on Better Outcomes for Children and Youth in Eastern and Northern Uganda. The program goal is to improve the wellbeing of children and youth orphaned by HIV and other adversities in Uganda. It mainly focuses on orphaned and vulnerable children, youth and their caregivers to have improved access and utilization of health, nutrition, education, and psychosocial wellbeing and reducing abuse, exploitation and neglect. The Economic Strengthening Officer will be responsible for the day to day implementation of the economic strengthening components of the program in collaboration with consortium members. The sector priorities include meeting immediate economic needs of the most vulnerable target groups though temporary interventions to uplift and integrate them in to market systems; increased savings and access to credit opportunities; increased opportunities for income growth and building assets; and better access to group based education and support programming. The program will be implemented in Northern and Eastern Uganda. GENERAL POSITION SUMMARY: The Economic Strengthening Officer will responsible for the implementation of the economic empowerment component of the program in northern Uganda. S/he will be responsible for activity planning and implementation to improve the economic conditions of target groups through improved access and utilization of services and products and better access to markets. Reporting to the Economic Strengthening Technical Lead, the Officer will work with a consortium of agencies under the prime lead of World Education. ESSENTIAL JOB FUNCTIONS: With guidance from the technical lead, the officer will be responsible for program planning and implementation in the areas of economic strengthening. Work closely with other component field teams in the consortium to ensure integrated approach to program implementation Establish and maintain productive working relationships with local government officials and line departments, soliciting their participation in all activities where appropriate. Responsible for the day to day implementation of activities at field level. Ensure proper logistics, administration, human resources and transport needs of the program are conducted within Mercy Corps policy and with the maximum benefit to the program. Work with the economic strengthening team for the development of and continual revision of a dynamic, program-wide monitoring and evaluation system linked to program strategies, indicators, and information management tools, which supports program management, accountability and learning. Continual gathering and sharing of data specific to the sector Produce written reports on the program capturing impacts related to all activities. Ensure establishment and maintenance of relationships with communities, consortium partners and other CSOs in target operation areas. KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE: o A degree, preferably graduate level, in economics development, development studies, social sciences or social work, or a closely related field is required. o S/he must have at least three years of works experience in economic strengthening initiatives that target vulnerable communities mainly orphan and vulnerable children and households. o Experience in working with private sector partners o Solid experience on market based solutions to addressing poverty o Strong interpersonal, writing and oral presentation skills in English are also required. o Demonstrated attention to detail, ability to follow procedures, meet deadlines and work independently and cooperatively with team members. o Strong computer literacy with a full knowledge of office applications. o Ability to focus on day-to-day tasks at hand while also working towards longer-term objectives with an understanding that these will change continuously; o Willingness to spend much time in the field and work closely with program target groups and partners. SUCCESS FACTORS: o The successful Economic Strengthening Officer will have the ability and curiosity to work effectively with local government, civil society and community based organizations. o The successful candidate will have solid background in economic and market development. How to apply: Applications: Submit your application through email to ug-mcjobs@mercycorps.org addressed to the Senior HR and Legal Manager, Mercy Corps Uganda. Include a cover letter clearly stating your salary requirements, CV (with 3 referees), and copies of academic qualifications/certificates. Deadline for Submission: Close of business on Thursday, 17th November, 2016. Subject of email should include the position you are applying for. Only short-listed candidates will be contacted by Mercy Corps. Mercy Corps is an equal opportunity employer; qualified female candidates are strongly encouraged to apply. Job ID: #1771066 Career categories: Program/Project Management Country: Uganda Organization: Mercy Corps Job years of experience: 3-5 years Job type: Job How to apply Home Updates Countries Disasters Topics Organizations Jobs Training About Us Help ReliefWeb Informing humanitarians worldwide. Learn more about ReliefWeb Still relevant after all these years ReliefWeb is not only pertinent in a disaster environment or humanitarian emergency ; indeed, the users I canvassed in Nairobi, the biggest hub for humanitarian actors in Africa, pointed to all... Shocking moment a man ‘is robbed while he has a seizure’ at busy supermarket – but not all is what it seems Footage shows crowd of shoppers standing back as brazen 'thief' walks away with wallet By NEAL BAKER 8th November 2016, 10:57 pm THIS is the shocking moment a brazen thief steals the wallet of a man having a seizure — but not all is what it seems. The footage, shot at a busy Walmart supermarket in Philadelphia, shows a man collapsing in front of shoppers before a passerby appears to rob him. Not known 3 ‘Theft’ … Supposed pickpocket can be seen bending over to take seizure victim’s wallet as crowds look on Not known 3 Wallet thief coolly walks away from his ‘victim’ while shoppers stand by idly But the incident is a set-up designed to test how people react to a blatant crime — and the result is shocking. Not one person intervenes to stop the ‘thief’ as he coolly walks out of the shop having just pick-pocketed the apparent victim. The shocking stunt has raised questions over the public’s ability to turn a blind eye to crime. Related stories CATCH THE POPPY THIEF Moment shameless crook swipes Poppy Appeal collection tin from busy restaurant HAVE A BREAK in Hungry thief steals a Kit-Kat out of student's car... and leaves grovelling apology behind HOW COULD HE? Police hunting thief who stole poppy charity collection from McDonald's THIS IS A PRICKUP! 'Thief holds syringe against pregnant cashier's neck and threatens to stab her' AMAZON CRIME Retail giant Amazon slammed for selling lock picks dubbed 'a thief's dream' MUGGER DEATH Suspected street thief dies moments after being 'arrested' by members of the public 'as low as it can get' Judge blasts 'callous' thief who stole a murder victim’s phone as he lay dying then threw it away HE MUST THINK WE'RE BLIND! Moment bungling thief tries to hide a Venetian BLIND under his coat STABBED ON THE JOB Police dog fighting for its life after suspected thief stabbed him and his handler Not known 3 ‘Thief’ escapes without being stopped by any witnesses While one bystander — who appears to be calling an ambulance for the supposed seizure victim — shouts at the thief, others stand idle as he slowly strolls away. As he leaves the store shouts increase in volume, but still no one stands in his way. The footage was uploaded to YouTube by user Chris Mendez who posts prank clips filmed in the Philadelphia area. “What happened afterwards [was] they screamed at us for playing around and we just left”, he said describing the stunt. Do you have a story for The Sun Online news team? Last year sweet potato pies with the music legend’s face on the box sold out in a flash at Walmart thanks to a viral video review, leading LaBelle to expand the line with cakes. (Sadly, they are not called Patti Cakes.) Now, LaBelle’s onto the natural next phase of her lifestyle branding: a cooking show. The Cooking Channel has ordered six half-hour episodes of her new series Patti LaBelle’s Place, set to debut next month. LaBelle will enlist a healthy roster of celebrity guest stars — 50 Cent! Oprah’s BFF Gayle King! Carla Hall! — to help her whip up homey-sounding dishes, many of which boast her name in the title (think Patti’s Southern-Style Fried Corn and Patti’s Secret Homemade Salad Dressing, which will presumably no longer be a secret once it’s broadcast on national television). Her new cooking show debuts December 3 with two back-to-back episodes. Merry and Bright Holiday Gifts 1:49 pm Military Minute: USS Stout 3:56 pm Audience: Holiday Lights at the Beach 1:45 pm Experts More About Us Advertise with Us Contact Us Staff Bios Community Calendar Contests Work for Us WAVY Archives Mobile Apps Email Alerts Text Alerts Report It TV Schedule Face of FOX 43 hrScene.com Search for: Search the site 57° F Overcast Hi: 58° F Lo: 42° F Missing man last seen leaving his Portsmouth home Friday By Emily Satchell Published: November 8, 2016, 4:33 pm Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window) Click to share on Google+ (Opens in new window) Share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window) Jason Hargraves, Sr. (Photo: Portsmouth Police Department) PORTSMOUTH, Va. (WAVY) — Portsmouth police are searching for a man missing since November 4. 36-year-old Jason Hargraves, Sr. was last seen at 8:30 p.m. Friday leaving his home in the tenth block of Muckle Court. Family members say Hargraves was heading to Wal-Mart and called an Uber driver to take him there. No one has heard from Hargraves since he left. Police described Hargraves as a black male, about 6 feet tall and 220 pounds. He has brown eyes and black hair. If you’ve seen Hargraves or have information about his whereabouts, call the Portsmouth Police Department at 757-393-5300 or the Crime Line at 1-888-LOCK-U-UP. Daily Journal Daily Journal Chickasaw Journal Monroe County Journal Pontotoc Progress Itawamba Times Southern Sentinel Southern Advocate New Albany Gazette Blogs Biz Buzz Scene Now Education Matters Inside Mississippi State Sports Inside Ole Miss Sports NeMiss Preps Real Estate NeMiss Jobs Classifieds Advertise Subscribe eEdition Contact Us Directory New Albany Gazette New Albany news & Union County MS Navigation Menu  Home About Us News New Albany Union County Blue Springs Myrtle Education Community News Milestones Public Records Business Sports New Albany East Union Ingomar Myrtle West Union Columns Opinion Editorials Columns Letters Bridal View Announcements Submit Announcement Obituaries Visit Latest Obituaries View Archived Obituaries Classifieds eEdition Best Ballot ’16   City updates fee-related ordinances among other agenda items By Lynn West on November 8, 2016 in News New Albany aldermen modified a series of city ordinances at their monthly meeting this past week, but said rather than effecting major change the move just made regulations more flexible. Most of the changes referred to outmoded permit and related fees that were set by law years ago. Now, planning and zoning board members will have the ability to update them as needed rather than going through a more protracted legal process. One other change will give the zoning administrator the power to act concerning commercial vehicles that may be improperly parked in residential areas and yet another expanded the permitted use of light industrial zoning to include towing and vehicle storage. The last was to make laws regarding the advertising of beer and liquor conform to each other. Aldermen had wanted to prohibit such advertising inside a building that was visible from the outside and now that is true for both beer and light wine, and wine and spirits. Building inspector and zoning administrator Eric Thomas reported a good month with about $10,000 received in permit fees. He said John Ellis and Mrs. Richard Hamric had asked the board for permission to rezone adjoining lots at 202 and 204 Oxford Rd. from R-2 residential to C-2 commercial. This is on the edge of the area popoulated by medical-related offices behind the hospital. The planning and zoning board approved so a public hearing needs to be set before final approval by aldermen. The hearing will be at the next aldermen’s meeting in December. It appears the city will be adding to its inventory of speed tables and three-way stops. Aldermen agreed to install speed tables on Eastview after a request by 32 families living in the area because of the danger of speeding drivers to young children playing. This brought up discussion about a possible need for similar speed tables on Oxford Road behind Wal-Mart, and on Cleveland Street. Some aldermen expressed concern about a “snowball effect” in adding more and more speed control devices. “Now, everybody will be wanting one,” one board member said. Aldermen agreed the first choice was to try to increase police enforcement of speed limits before adding too many speed tables. In another traffic-related matter, the status of efforts to have a traffic light installed at the intersection of Hwy. 30 West and Starlyn Drive is unchanged, Mayor Tim Kent said. Transportation officials say a light is justified but they have no money for it. Alderman Johnny Anderson asked how much a light would cost and whether the city could install one, but estimates were in the $200,000 range including lights, poles and arms. Nothing new also was reported concerning repairing the rough railroad crossing on Glenfield Road, with Mayor Kent saying he had not heard back from railroad officials. There was also nothing new to report on the possibility of replacing the wooden railroad trestle where it passes over Snyder Street. Mayor Kent said he hopes work will be completed so Main Street can be opened in the next few days. Aldermen approved paying Paul Smithey $65,964.32 and $67,371.75 plus ESI engineers $8,852.90 toward the project. The money comes from a Mississippi Department of Wildlife, Fisheries and Parks grant and was used to cover Camp Creek Branch after installing large culverts and placing a concrete trail access path over it. Also included was the work now going on to place a large box culvert under Main Street beneath the Tanglefoot Trail bridge intended to end street flooding in the even of heavy rains. In department business: • Police Chief Chris Robertson asked for permission to apply for the FY ’18 DUI grant from the department of public safety. “We have got it for the past seven or eight years,” he told the board, adding that the grant helps pay for a full-time DUI officer plus overtime and extra enforcement during high-risk periods such as holidays. • Robertson also asked for and received permission to sell two abandoned vehicles. He said the Ford Expedition and Toyota Sequoia were seized on I-22 and driven by undocumented aliens, who were turned over to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. A 120-day waiting period was required before the vehicles can be sold and Robertson said no one has tried to claim them. Officers have been unable to contact anyone who might have filed a claim. • Light, gas and water manager Bill Mattox told the board that he needed to “beef up” the Butler Street substation and needs a new circuit breaker. Because the cost is expected to be more than $50,000, Mattox will need to advertise for bids. He said the breaker was included in the department budget. • Union County Development Association Executive Director Phil Nanney reported on the CREATE Foundation’s “Imagine the Possibilities” career fair held at the BancorpSouth Arena where more than 7,000 area eighth-graders were given hands-on exposure to 17 career paths encompassing many more different occupations. He said a career planning event was held especially for kindergarten students at the fairgrounds here recently as well. Nanney reported on use of the civic center for an Imperial Trading training meeting and told aldermen that the sale of 30 acres in the Martintown Industrial Park to the PUL Alliance had been completed. This is the land that will be used for the solar energy farm. • Assistant Fire Chief Mark Whiteside received permission to advertise for a hiring pool for the fire department. He said they do this once a year so that if an opening occurs they have qualified replacements waiting. Among agenda items: • Aldermen approved the October claims docket and minutes for the Oct. 4 and 17 meetings. • They elected Mayor Tim Kent to represent the city on the Three Rivers Solid Waste Authority board, which he has been serving on in the past. • Aldermen amended the budget to allow purchase of Bush-Hog for the street department. The item was inadvertently left out of the budget. • Aldermen approved a freeport tax exemption for Emerald Home Furnishings, which county supervisors had already approved as well. The exemption is on personal property that was not manufactured in the state or intended for sale here, but rather just being stored here on a temporary basis before reshipping. • The board voted to put a new roof on the community center, which has been experiencing leaks. The nearly 70-year-old building remains in frequent use. • Aldermen approve 10-year ad valorem tax exemptions for Albany Industries, Emerald King’s Creek, VIP Cinema, a second earlier year for VIP Cinema, Diversity Vuteq and Sugarees Bakery. • Before adjourning the board met in executive session concerning a personnel matter but Mayor Kent said they took no action. AccuWeather.com Quick Look Change your current location » View Full Weather Report Search Search Search Cleveland.com Account Sign In Close Sign in to Cleveland.com You are signed in as Edit Public Profile Sign Out Subscribe The Plain Dealer Sun News Media Insider Rewards comments Lake County woman loses $1,200 through fake sweepstakes scam Print Email Teresa Dixon Murray, The Plain Dealer By Teresa Dixon Murray, The Plain Dealer The Plain Dealer Email the author | Follow on Twitter on November 08, 2016 at 3:13 PM, updated November 08, 2016 at 3:15 PM comments   CLEVELAND, Ohio -- It was the phone call we'd all love to get. Jo of Lake County last month received a call that she'd won $2.5 million through the Publishers Clearing House sweepstakes. All that she need to do is send $295 to cover the taxes. So she arranged a wire transfer. Then when the gentleman called back the next day, he said he needed $995 more. She asked why he couldn't take the taxes out of her winnings, but agreed to wire transfer the additional $995. It wasn't until he called the third time and demanded $5,000 more that Jo got a really bad feeling. She talked to one of her children. She then called Publishers Clearing House and was told she'd been scammed. In fact, there's been a surge of Northeast Ohio residents who've been suckered by the exact same scam, according to Sue McConnell, president of the Better Business Bureau in Cleveland. Jo, who didn't want her full name used, said she's embarrassed that she fell for the ripoff. On one hand, she does actually buy merchandise from Publishers Clearing House, so she thought she might have won a jackpot. And, she said, the guy "was very convincing." On the other hand, the person who called asked her to do the wire transfer through Walmart. That's not the way taxes are normally paid. Publishers Clearing House told Jo to call the police and the BBB and, if the guy called again, to tell him she wouldn't be sending any more money. He called repeatedly over a period of days and she didn't cave. But she worried the thief might hunt her down at her home, if he knew where she lived. "I was never so scared in my life," she said. McConnell of the BBB said the tales of loss from consumers, who typically are senior citizens, are heart-breaking. "Not a day goes by here when we don't get a call about a phony sweepstakes," McConnell said. These sorts of scams have been around for years. Some involve people posing as IRS agents who calls someone and says the person owes back taxes. Some involve thieves who hack into someone's computer and convince the person the computer has a virus but can be fixed on the spot -- for a fee of perhaps $300. Other thieves call someone and pose as a grandchild who's in trouble and needs money wired immediately. "It often seems like this is old news," McConnell said. "But to someone, this is new. People find (these pitches) to be very believable." McConnell notes that many senior citizens don't report suspected incidents to authorities because either they're embarrassed or they're afraid of losing their financial independence if a relative finds out what happened. Senior citizens are particularly vulnerable to these sorts of ripoffs, McConnell said, because many don't have a lot of social contact and many are reluctant to end a suspicious phone call. "They feel it's rude and nasty and they don't want to just hang up on people." Back in Lake County, Jo wishes she had done something different. She realizes it's unlikely she'll get her $1,200 back. The mechanism she used, Walmart-2-Walmart funds, allows customers to send money that the recipient can pick up at any Walmart store nationwide. In the case of Publishers Clearing House, it should be noted that the company doesn't announce sweepstakes winners by phone and doesn't require any form of payment to receive winnings. For more information about the PCH scam, go to: http://info.pch.com/consumer-information/fraud-protection The BBB offers this advice to detect scams: You can't win a contest you didn't enter. It is illegal to require the payment of any sort of fee or the purchase of any item before getting sweepstakes winnings. If you get a call, letter or email that you won a prize, always ask a friend, a relative or your local BBB office to gut-check the information and sniff out a scam before you take any action.  Never, ever provide personal information, including your Social Security number, bank account number, credit card account number, date of birth or anything else, to a stranger over the phone or online. If you have older relatives or anyone you think may be vulnerable to such a scam, tell them about this Publishers Clearing House scam and other possible efforts to steal their money or con them into revealing personal information.  Check with the BBB at bbb.org/cleveland or call the BBB at 216-241-7678. Report the scam to bbb.org/scamtracker. Skip to content Satellite Press Releases Satellite Press Releases and News Ainsworth Pet Nutrition Donates to Shelter Impacted by Hurricane Matthew PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8, 2016 /PRNewswire/ — Ainsworth Pet Nutrition, a manufacturer of Pure Balance® – Walmart’s private brand of super premium pet food – announced today that it will donate more than 260,000 meals of Pure Balance dog food to Saving Animals from Euthanasia (S.A.F.E.) Pet Rescue of St. Augustine, Florida, which was impacted by Hurricane Matthew. S.A.F.E. Pet Rescue is comprised of three adoption centers, two in St. Augustine, and one in Hollister, Florida, located roughly 60 miles southwest St. Augustine.  As Hurricane Matthew approached the Florida coast, S.A.F.E. was forced to evacuate more than 150 dogs and cats to their Hollister location, which was already housing approximately 75 animals.  Despite a lack of electricity and air conditioning and a tense and crowded environment, the organization was able to keep all of their animals safe and dry during the storm, however, the financial impact will be felt for some time. “During times of emergency, keeping our animals safe is always our top priority, however this commitment doesn’t come without cost,” said Robin Kantner Nordan, Founder, S.A.F.E. Pet Rescue.  “The cost of transport, emergency and veterinary fees and 24-hour staffing during the storm were significant.  This generous donation from Ainsworth Pet Nutrition will ease the financial burden of feeding the 195 dogs in our care for quite some time.  We are very grateful.” “At Ainsworth Pet Nutrition, our commitment to helping animals in need goes beyond doing what’s right, it is engrained in who we are as an organization,” said Steve Joyce, Vice President of Marketing for Ainsworth Pet Nutrition.  “When we heard about S.A.F.E. Pet Rescue and what they had been through during Hurricane Matthew, we knew we needed to do something to help.  We are so happy that this donation will be beneficial to the shelter and the animals in their care.” Pure Balance super-premium food for dogs and cats is available exclusively at Walmart.  Each recipe is designed without any corn, wheat or soy and is prepared with carefully selected ingredients like real chicken, carrots, peas, and flaxseed.  Made with natural ingredients with added vitamins and minerals, Pure Balance makes premium pet nutrition available to Walmart shoppers without a special trip to the pet store. The donation will be delivered to the S.A.F.E. Pet Rescue within the next week.  ABOUT AINSWORTH PET NUTRITION Founded in 1933, Ainsworth Pet Nutrition is a fifth generation, primarily family-owned and operated company headquartered in Western Pennsylvania and focused entirely on pets.  With a goal of changing the way consumers shop for Super Premium pet food, Ainsworth’s mantra is “Pet Store Quality.  Supermarket Easy.” They achieve this promise by providing consumers with the high-quality pet food where they currently shop for the rest of their families.  The company makes multiple brands and types of dog and cat food, including the Rachael Ray™ Nutrish® line, as well as Super Premium retailer specific brands.  Ainsworth Pet Nutrition is committed to food safety and prepares all of its dry pet food in the United States using high-quality, natural ingredients with added vitamins and minerals.  To learn more, visit www.ainsworthpets.com. Contact: Samantha Bridger – 724-272-1757 Logo – http://photos.prnewswire.com/prnh/20161108/437164LOGO satprnews.com Author RSS ImportPosted on November 8, 2016Categories Uncategorized Post navigation Previous Previous post: ARUP Scientist Receives the 2017 Diagnostics Young Investigator by the American Society of Microbiology Next Next post: CBIS CEO, Mr. Dabney Prepares for Exclusive Harvard Medical School Drug Development Briefing as the Nation Votes on a Number of Historic Events Search for: Search Recent Posts Pure Multi-Family REIT LP Announces Release of Third Quarter Financial Results and Conference Call Indian Steel Industry 2016-2020 Global Text-to-speech Education Technology Market 2016-2020 MB Financial, Inc. Technology Apple Science Cars Celebrity Movies Business Black Friday Holiday Gifts     Fiat Chrysler Plans To Stick With Big Cars Until 2020 Posted: Nov 8 2016, 1:16pm CST | by M. Affan, in News | Cars & Vehicles   FCA’s Large Vehicles are here to stay till at least 2020   The LX based RWD cars extended till the end of current decade The famous and bog Dodge Challenger and Dodge Charger are here to stay with us for the next coming four years. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles have recently made the decision to stick with producing these big cars. Don't Miss: Best Amazon Black Friday 2016 Deals It was rumored earlier on that these cars will be discontinued soon, however according to the news by Automotive News, these cars are here to stay till at least 2020, according to Automotive News. The information was provided by two unnamed sources who had this inside information and confirmed the details of Fiat’s new contract with Unifor which is Canada’s auto union for labors. The company is planning to refresh the Challenger, and Charger both along with 300 until these vehicles are switched to FCA’s new Giorgio Platform in the future. The Giorgio platform is actually used by Alfa Romeo Giulia and is currently in its use. It is supposed to make way in three new and large American vehicle in the year 2021 as well. It also predicted that FCA will either discontinue Charger or 300 as per these changes in the year 2021.  If we are looking to bid farewell to any vehicle among these three then it’s most likely to be 300. The platform of 300 which is based on LX will be almost 15 years old in the year 2020. Thus it will be the best choice for the company to move forward and to introduce a new one at its place. The Charger was switched from LX platform to LD platform in 2010. On the other hand Challenger was also switched from LC platform to LA platform recently. It is only 300 which was not given any update. Thus we are hoping to see Challenger and Charger in a way after 2020.  You May Like The Author M. Affan M. Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about FacebookEmailTwitterGoogle+LinkedInPinterest A short history lesson on presidents winning without the popular vote 2000 election was the most recent when the candidate who received the greatest number of electoral votes didn’t win the popular vote. Post to Facebook A short history lesson on presidents winning without the popular vote 2000 election was the most recent when the candidate who received the greatest number of electoral votes didn’t win the popular vote.   Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2fx5JuZ {# #} CancelSend Sent! A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 62 Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Election Results Election Outlook Latest Election News A short history lesson on presidents winning without the popular vote D'Angelo Gore, FactCheck.org 12:11 p.m. EST November 8, 2016 108k Shares In this Nov. 12, 2000, file photo, fans are dressed as George W. Bush and Al Gore during a Tampa Bay Buccaneers game.  (Photo: Steve Nesius, AP) Q: How many times was a president elected who did not win the popular vote?  A: It has happened four times. The 2000 election was the most recent when the candidate who received the greatest number of electoral votes, and thus won the presidency, didn’t win the popular vote. But this scenario has played out in our nation’s history before. In 1824, John Quincy Adams was elected president despite not winning either the popular vote or the electoral vote. Andrew Jackson was the winner in both categories. Jackson received 38,000 more popular votes than Adams, and beat him in the electoral vote 99 to 84. Despite his victories, Jackson didn’t reach the majority 131 votes needed in the Electoral College to be declared president. In fact, neither candidate did. The decision went to the House of Representatives, which voted Adams into the White House. In 1876, Rutherford B. Hayes won the election (by a margin of one electoral vote), but he lost the popular vote by more than 250,000 ballots to Samuel J. Tilden. In 1888, Benjamin Harrison received 233 electoral votes to Grover Cleveland’s 168, winning the presidency. But Harrison lost the popular vote by more than 90,000 votes. In 2000, George W. Bush was declared the winner of the general election and became the 43rd president, but he didn’t win the popular vote either. Al Gore holds that distinction, garnering about 540,000 more votes than Bush. However, Bush won the electoral vote, 271 to 266. A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 9 Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Election Results Election Outlook Latest Election News People are asking Google: Who is on my ballot? Who is Taylor Swift voting for? Ashley May , USA TODAY 4:26 p.m. EST November 8, 2016 1.5k Shares People really want to know who Taylor Swift is voting for.  (Photo: SUZANNE CORDEIRO, AFP/Getty Images) Election Day is all about the issues, like who is Taylor Swift voting for? And, who is running again? Hopefully, Americans know Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump are candidates for president, but who can be sure, according to recent Google Trends data. The No. 1 question people have googled in the last few hours is: Who is on my ballot? Other popular questions: Where do I vote? What time do polls open? What time will the President be announced? What do I need to bring to vote? USA TODAY These Election Day hashtags will generate emojis on Twitter When looking at searches of “Who is ____ voting for," these names are the most popular: Taylor Swift Monica Lewinsky George Bush Al Gore Mitt Romney If Google search is any indicator of the next president, Clinton is pulling ahead. As of this morning, Clinton has 51% of search interest compared to Trump’s 49%. Trump was pulling ahead in Michigan, Ohio and Nevada while Clinton topped searches in Florida, North Carolina and Texas, Google Trends reports. On the flip side, search interest in "Republican" is 173% higher than search interest in “Democrat." Visit the Google Trends map to see in real-time what issues people are searching for this Election Day. Nearby: Blue Valley Post Shawnee Mission Post - Neighborhood news and events for northeast Johnson County About Obits Events Sports Advertise Local Businesses Columns: Your Home Shawnee Mission Health Update Spaces for Life Mortgage 101 NEJC Chamber Estate Planning KC Facebook Twitter RSS Email Roeland Park looking at removing traffic signals along Roe Blvd. Posted by Jay Senter  · November 8, 2016 11:42 am · Comments Tweet Roe Boulevard cuts through the heart of the Roeland Park commercial district. By Holly Cook Roeland Park city council members on Monday heard recommendations to improve traffic flow in the section of Roe Boulevard from W. 48th Street to W. 52nd Street. CVS, Walmart, Price Chopper and Walgreens are among the business located along this .4 mile stretch of Roe Boulevard that contains five traffic signals. FROM OUR SPONSORS: The traffic study recommended removing signals at Bella Roe Plaza/Walgreen’s and Roe Boulevard and at W. 52nd Street and Roe Boulevard. Removing and redirecting through and left-turn movement on from the east and west legs of the Bella Roe Plaza/Walgreen’s intersection was also recommended. Following these changes the remaining three traffic signals would need timing updates and improvements. Approximately 34,875 people travel through the Roe Boulevard corridor each day. The proposed changes are expected to decrease the total amount of stops for vehicles during peak hours by 450 and save 10.7 hours in total travel time. The report, conducted by engineering firm Shafer, Kline, and Warren, is meant to be incorporated into the larger discussion to rebuild Roe Boulevard in 2020. Director of Public Works Jose Leon said the most frequent complaint he hears is that there are too many traffic signals on Roe Boulevard. Leon said the traffic study was “long overdue.” City Administrator Keith Moody also said the city has received significant feedback on the amount of time it takes to use Roe Boulevard as a commuter route. Moody said he expected the recommendations would spur community discussions. “We realize this is something that will be political,” he said. Engineer Cheryl Bornheimer said the traffic signal at W. 52nd Street was initially meant to facilitate an easier entrance and exit for large trucks but that the report found the light was mostly being used by passenger cars. Councilmember Michael Rhoades asked if the traffic signals being removed could be repurposed for the redevelopment plan at Roeland Park’s old pool site. City staff responded that could be discussed. The traffic lights targeted for removal are owned by KCP&L and the city may need to pay a fine to have them removed since they were placed so recently, Moody said. Councilmember Teresa Kelly said she would like councilors to consider all types of transportation, including biking and walking, when discussing Roe Boulevard improvements. Monday’s presentation was solely for informational purposes. City staff said the next step is to initiate determining the scope and cost of the recommendations. FROM OUR SPONSORS: Comment Categories : Roeland Park, Traffic Previous Post Next Post Comments Comments Related Roeland Park looking for help to stand out in the crowd Roeland Park administrators say requirement to screen trash bins is too difficult to enforce Roeland Park in discussions with potential tenants for old pool site Spotlight on Local Rowan Property Management Rowan Property Management is a full-service property management company, handling single & multi-family homes, condominium complexes, and apartment buildings throughout the greater Kansas City Metropolitan area. The incident was first reported shortly after 8:30 a.m. Local fire companies were dispatched to the scene at 709 South Broadway. Reports said there was the odor of gas around the building. The building was evacuated as a precaution and people remained outside as of 9:30 a.m., authorities said. Officials were awaiting the arrival of gas company representatives. I asked my 13-year old son last night how he thought the election would go. His answer: Bad — somebody is going to win. Of all the things this election will impact, I wonder if apathy levels of a future generation of voters are among them. Oh well, at least I have local news about two of the most American of foods: pizza and burritos. Spin! Pizza has announced it will open the doors of its new west Lawrence location on Monday. (Is it appropriate I have news of a restaurant called Spin! on election day?) We have reported on the restaurant several times. It will open in a new commercial building just east of the Wal-Mart near Sixth and Wakarusa. It will be next door to another new establishment, the Blue Moose Bar & Grill. Spin! got its start in Kansas City, and the menu was developed by Michael Smith, a James Beard award winning chef. Pizza, of course, is the featured item of the menu, but it also includes antipasti (not to be confused with antipasta, which is a position that is sure to hurt you in every poll), fresh soups, sandwiches and some Green Party creation called “salads.” The dessert menu also features something called creamy “piccolo” gelato, which is my second favorite kind of gelato. (Creamy tuba gelato is my favorite.) In case you are curious, I think piccolo refers to the 4 oz serving size. As for the pizza, it is Neapolitan style, which means a thin crust. The restaurant, however, isn’t thin on toppings to put atop the crust. In addition to all your standard pizza toppings, the menu also includes items like shrimp scampi, goat cheese, arugula, glazed pecans, pesto, and even fig marmalade, for when you get that craving. Lawrence’s Spin! will be owned by area businessman Brent Boles. He has decided to have the restaurant participate in a program called Token for your Kindness. The program involves giving elementary school teachers and coaches tokens that they can then give out to students who they see are doing something kind. Each token can be redeemed for a mini pizza and gelato. “We have made it our mission to help generate kindness in Lawrence,” Boles said in a release. “With this in mind, we decided to start in our classrooms and on the playing field/court.” • I also have burrito news. Qdoba opened its Lawrence restaurant on Monday. As we have reported, the restaurant is located just west of 23rd and Ousdahl in the spot that formerly housed a Kwik Shop. It is the only Lawrence restaurant for the chain, although it once briefly operated in downtown Lawrence. Remember where? It is where Ingredient is now located, which of course, serves thin crusts pizza, sandwiches, salads and soups. (The food universe works in mysterious ways — and, in the process, usually ruins three of my ties a week with pizza sauce or salsa.) As for Qdoba, I assume most of you already are familiar with the chain. It is similar to Chipoltle, but has a broader menu. In addition to the Mexican wraps and bowls, it also has tacos, nachos, quesdillas, and soups and salads served in crispy bowls you can eat. The new Qdoba restaurant on 23rd Street in Lawrence. by Chad Lawhorn Print Comment E-mail to a friend Facebook Tweet LinkedIn StumbleUpon Google + Tumblr Wordpress Reddit Copy and paste the link: Comments Use the comment form below to begin a discussion about this content. Search Contact Us Sign In | Sign Up Home Shows Program Schedule Rob Snyder Listen Listen Live Mobile Events Calendar Game Schedule Sports News Hotties Babe Of The Day Contact Help & Contact Info Feedback Advertise Follow on Facebook Follow on Twitter subscribe via RSS Trending Now TTU Football Coverage TTU Clear Bag Policy TTU Schedule Broncos on The Fan Texans on Awesome 98 All Sports News Fan Game Schedule What Do All the Green Light Bulbs in Lubbock Mean? By Jan Miller November 7, 2016 6:48 PM Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Photo: Jan Miller, Lonestar 99.5 FM You can show your support for Veterans this Veteran’s Day when you turn on a green light. The initiative, which you can learn more about at Greenlightavet.com, asks people to “change one light in a visible location in your home or office to green, and keep it glowing every day as a symbol of support and appreciation for our veterans.” There are stories from across the country of sold out shelves of green light bulbs, so I went out to investigate. Most of our local Walmarts still have plenty of green light bulbs in stock. Food King’s Ace Hardware said they had sold out, but were expecting to have green light bulbs in on Wednesday. At Home Depot, they only have a few left and the man who helped me said he was a veteran and had just learned of the initiative. I was glad for the opportunity to talk to him about the Green Light a Vet project and thanked him for his service. If you know of any other places that are selling green light bulbs, please let us know in the comments or on our Facebook page. Greenlightavet.com also gives us more ways to show our support by sharing the #greenlightavet hashtag, by green lighting our profile picture and by mapping our location so veterans everywhere can see how many of us are thankful for their service. This is such a great way to show our support,  It’s simple but powerful and imagine how great it will be when little by little we have more green lights up for these incredible men and women. Our Veterans have made an extreme sacrifice and deserve all the show of support we can offer. shoplifting Delta couple charged with Oxford shoplifting Posted on November 8, 2016 by William Moore in Crime & Law Enforcement, News STEWART CONNER OXFORD – A man and woman from Clarksdale were arrested Sunday after trying to steal numerous items from an Oxford store. Walmart employees told police they saw two people taking multiple items off the shelves and placing them in garbage cans throughout the store. Oxford police officers were waiting outside the store when the suspects exited with the stolen items. Tamara Stewart 41, and Demitrius Conner, 42, were arrested and charged with shoplifting. Bond was set at $2,500 each. Click here to leave a comment! A sheriff’s office report stated a vehicle had been rummaged through but nothing was taken. • Burglary to a vehicle was reported Oct. 28 in the 5N500 block of Cochise Drive, Maple Park. A sheriff’s office report stated a black-handled pocket knife, silver Zippo lighter and a small bottle of lighter fluid were taken. • Burglary to a vehicle was reported Oct. 28 in the 42W500 block of Jens Jensen Lane, St. Charles. A sheriff’s office report stated about $20 in coins was taken. • Muhammad U. Chaudhary, 21, of the 4700 block of North Kenton Avenue, Chicago, was charged Oct. 28 with driving on a suspended or revoked license. • Adrian Urbieta, 35, of the 700 block of Deborah Avenue, Elgin, was charged Oct. 29 with driving without a valid driver’s license. • Theft of about $280 was reported Oct. 29 at Black Sheep Golf Club, 2S610 Seavey Road, Sugar Grove. A sheriff’s office report stated two flag markers valued at $140 each were taken from the club. • Theft less than $300 was reported Oct. 30 along South Hathaway Lane in Geneva. A sheriff’s office report stated that a binder fell off a car with personal papers and a Social Security card inside. Tuesday 15 Nov 2016 / Tehran - 04:37 / GMT - 01:07 Old FNA Old FNA                 Advanced Search Ar  | En  | Fa  | Tr Home Politico-Defense Politics  - Foreign Policy  - Defense  - Nuclear   Economy Society & Culture Society  - Sport  - Culture  - Art  - Life Style   Sci-Tech Space  - Nano  - Medicine  - Technology  - Earth   World Interviews & Commentaries Interviews  - Commentaries   Multimedia Photo  - Video   All Stories World Tue Nov 08, 2016 6:36 US Election Chaos Fears Prompt Preppers Stockpiling Survival Food Tweet TEHRAN (FNA)- Preppers in US began running up sales of emergency survival food in case of an election night Doomsday as Voting in US presidential election started on Tuesday. While sales for "long term food" typically see an increase around natural disasters and elections, "this is more intense than what we saw in 2012," said Keith Bansemer, VP of marketing for My Patriot Supply, a manufacturer and seller of survival food, NBC reported. During the previous election his company saw sales double. This time it's triple. "We have everyone we can on the phones," he said. "We are overwhelmed." Purchases at other long term food supply companies are up as well. Emergency preparedness online store TheEpicenter reports a 6 percent uptick in year over year sales. Another company, Legacy Foods, predicts they'll see a 1-2 week spike in sales after the election, if Hillary Clinton wins, said owner Phil Cox. The meals, sold by the plastic bucket or tote bin, are typically dehydrated or freeze-dried food in sealed military-grade Mylar packs. Menu items include pasta primavera, Hawaiian Style Sweet n' Sour, cheesy broccoli and rice soup, orange energy drink mix and chocolate pudding. They're sold in bundles based on how long they'll feed you. Big name retailers are in on the game. Costco sells a 1-month supply of 390 servings in plastic gallon buckets for $114.99. Wal-Mart has a bucket deal, too. What's feeding this new urgency? Survivalist consumers says they're preparing for post-election unrest that could involve everything from massive riots, to power grid outages, to the total collapse of the financial system where a can of food becomes currency. And it's not just guys digging a hole on their farm and filling it with MRE's who are driving sales, companies say, but schoolteachers, moms, and successful financial planners. Nor is it limited to just rural areas. "Frederick Reddie," a 41-year-old "urban prepper" from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania is stocking up on staples like rice and peanut butter and working on expanding his 6-month supply of emergency food to two years. He has to use a pseudonym to protect his supply from any future hungry neighbors, he told NBC News. Reddie predicts a Trump win that has the urban poor revolting across the nation and the imposition of martial law to quell riots and the burning of businesses. But he's also getting ready for the possibility of a Clinton victory that he says could lead to conflict with Russia and "World War 3 in 2017." Either way, Freddy's ready, with both supplies and a word of advice. "At minimum stock up your cabinets as if you knew a hurricane was coming," he said. "It'll be like a hurricane that could touch every city in America." The companies take pains to point out that they sell food not just for the collapse of civilization but also for camping, outdoor recreation, and natural disaster preparedness, like Ebola or volcanoes. Their customers are careful, self-sufficient and pragmatic types, they say, students of history who know things like stock market bubbles and crashes go in cycles and are taking small, meaningful steps, to reassert control over a toxic election. They're always thinking ahead. Cans of food that last 25 years are "better than money in the bank," said Nelson. "If you think the value of money is going to go down, then you could convert dollars into something tangible that you can use later" for either eating or barter. Bansemer said that his customers don't necessarily fear a specific election outcome, but change itself. "You hear them saying, no matter who wins, I know I could take a positive step myself and secure what's important," he said. "They're securing their food supply."         LATEST STORIES (5) Anti-Trump Protests Break out in Chicago Aerial Footage Shows Syrian Army Advances in Southwestern Damascus Syrian Army Missile Hits Militants' Gathering in Southern Aleppo Hashd Al-Shaabi Kicks Off 3rd Phase of Military Operations West of Mosul Anti-Trump Protests Continue across US Cities Spokesman: Iran's Missile Power Not Negotiable Tasting Justice: ISIL Being Driven Away in Iraq and Syria Iran, Russia Stress Boosting Mutual Cooperation Spokesman: AEOI Not Concerned About Trump Aides' Remarks Hashd Al-Shaabi Rescues 300 Sunni Families Battle for Mosul Day 28: Hashd Al-Sha'abi Kicks Off 3rd Phase of Mosul Operation Russia, Iran Plan $10bln Arms Deal Report: Russian Strategic Bombers Prepare to Strike Terrorists in Syria Samples Taken in Syria's Aleppo Prove Militants Used Chlorine Gas Syria: Jeish Al-Fatah Declares State of Emergency in Aleppo Anti-Trump Protests Break out in Chicago TEHRAN (FNA)- Demonstrators in Chicago took to the streets to continue protests against the election of Donald Trump and show common hate against him. Syria: Jeish Al-Fatah Declares State of Emergency in Aleppo TEHRAN (FNA)- Jeish al-Fatah has ordered all its militants in Aleppo to stay on the alert after reports indicated that the Syrian army is preparing to launch a massive assault in the region, media sources disclosed Monday. ﻿ ﻿ Sections Home World Politico-Defense Interviews Economy Multimedia Society & Culture All Stories Sci-Tech About us Contact us Fars News Agency Fars News Agency. Photo by Cristina M. Fletes, cfletes@post-dispatch.com Buy Now Cristina M. "I can't believe I'm doing this but the deals are too good," said Dobken. Photo by Cristina M. Fletes, cfletes@post-dispatch.com Buy Now From left to right, Bharat Malgave, Rohit Gupta and Rohit Bhatia, all of St. Louis, look at TVs during Thanksgiving day shopping at the Best Buy in Brentwood on Thursday, Nov. 26, 2015. Photo by Cristina M. Fletes, cfletes@post-dispatch.com Buy Now FILE PHOTO: Kim Brinkley, of St. Louis, helps customers during Thanksgiving day shopping at Target in Brentwood on Thursday, Nov. 26, 2015. Photo by Cristina M. Fletes, cfletes@post-dispatch.com NEW YORK • Thanksgiving Day shopping — a delight to some, anathema to others — isn’t going away, but some stores are rethinking their strategies on whether it makes sense to be open on the holiday itself. Many of the nation’s major mall operators and the big retailers that anchor them, such as Toys R Us, J.C. Penney and Macy’s, are sticking with what they want to be a new tradition, kicking off the holiday shopping season on Thanksgiving Day. Big-box retailers Walmart, Target and Best Buy also plan to open on the holiday. Others, including the Mall of America, the nation’s largest shopping mall, are closing for Thanksgiving this year after being open for the past several years. Some retailers that are closing cite respect for the holiday, but in truth the cost of being open may be more than the return. “Once you let the genie out of the bottle, it’s hard,” said Stephen D. Lebovitz, president and CEO of CBL & Associates Properties, a mall operator that is closing 72 of its malls, including four in the St. Louis area, for the day. “More retailers are coming to their senses and realizing it is a family holiday and from a business point of view, it’s not making much business sense.” Stores being open on Thanksgiving started in earnest in 2011 and took a punch out of sales on Black Friday, which had usually launched the shopping season. Many places like Macy’s, Target and J.C. Penney have been opening earlier and earlier on Thanksgiving as they try to outdo others to get first dibs on customers who could easily buy online. But the move has been controversial, as many workers have voiced complaints that stores are putting profits over workers’ time to be with their families. Some 89 of the 145 properties that Chattanooga, Tenn.-based CBL owns or has interest in opened at 6 p.m. on the holiday last year. Though dozens of those will be closed this year, the department stores, movie theaters, restaurants and retailers with exterior entrances have the option to open on Thanksgiving. Other retailers, including Office Depot and consumer electronics chain hhgregg Inc., plan to be closed after being open for the past several years. Plenty of retailers, particularly high-end stores such as Nordstrom or those such as T.J. Maxx that offer discounts every day, never opened on Thanksgiving and have collected goodwill because of that. In reality, analysts say, it’s all about stealing share in a market that isn’t growing that much. For department stores, the competition is fierce. Last year, J.C. Penney opened at 3 p.m. for the first time, three hours earlier than its rivals Kohl’s and Macy’s. That may have hurt Macy’s, which had a weak holiday season and aims to reverse a sales slump. This year, Macy’s decided to open an hour earlier at 5 p.m. on Thanksgiving. Penney is sticking to 3 p.m., while Kohl’s will be opening again at 6 p.m. Most Sears stores will be open on Thanksgiving for the fourth year in a row, starting at 6 p.m. — the same as a year ago. Best Buy, the nation’s largest consumer electronics chain, suffered over Thanksgiving weekend in 2012 because it didn’t open until midnight, while stores such as Walmart and Target began their sales earlier in the evening. This year, most Best Buy stores will open at 5 p.m. on Thanksgiving. Walmart and Target will kick off in-store Black Friday sales at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving again this year. Both chains said their online Black Friday sales would start in the early morning hours on Thanksgiving. For many big retailers, covering expenses such as paying employees holiday pay is not that costly, said Joel Bines, a managing director at retail consulting group AlixPartners. But for small stores or those with specialized merchandise, it may make more sense to close. AlixPartners also found that some retailers who did open on Thanksgiving were simply pulling Friday sales a day earlier and their profit margins took a hit. Bob Riesbeck, president and CEO of hhgregg, says business on Thanksgiving actually declined over the previous two years when it opened at 4 p.m. Meet the top midsized workplaces in St. Louis See how St. Louis stocks are faring How do they stack up? Compare pay of top St. Louis executives Who's hired? Check our People in Business CBL’s Lebovitz says when he surveyed stores in the company’s malls this year before deciding to close, the reaction was “overwhelmingly positive,” particularly with the specialty stores. The big anchors plan to stay open. Last year, the reaction was different. Most of the specialty stores wanted to be open. “They didn’t have enough data” to make the decision, he said. Andy Mantis, executive vice president of NPD Group Checkout Tracking, says stores should open on both Thanksgiving and Black Friday to maximize their sales. The company, which analyzes receipt data to understand consumer behavior, found that the share of buyers who shopped on both days declined, while the number who shopped only on Thanksgiving Day or on Black Friday increased. Mantis believes specialty retailers, especially those near big stores such as Macy’s that are open, should think again about whether to stay closed. “It is a heavy promotion time,” Mantis said. “People are buying, and they’re not always willing to go to multiple stores.” Business Briefing from St. Louis Post-Dispatch Make it your business. Get twice-daily updates on what the St. Louis business community is talking about. This field is required. Company About Us About 24-7 Press Release Executive Team Clients Newsletter Newsletter Sign-Up Affiliate Program Become an Affiliate What's New Newsroom Blog Testimonials What Our Customers Say Submit a Testimonial Toll Free Telephone 1-888-880-9539 Hours of Business M-F 8:30am - 5:00pm PST Follow Us Through Social Media All Press Releases for November 08, 2016 » Email This Story Printer Friendly PDF Version RSS Feed Laura Shorette Recognized by Worldwide Branding for Excellence in Transportation and Logistics Ms. Shorette looks forward to experiencing continued growth for her company The company partners with its customers to provide transportation expertise in the multimodal shipping supply chain as well as offer cross-dock, warehouse and fulfillment services.     CULLEOKA, TN, November 08, 2016 /24-7PressRelease/ -- Laura Shorette, President and Founder of Time Logistics, Inc., has been recognized for showing dedication, leadership and excellence in transportation and logistics. Worldwide Branding, the world's leading international personal branding organization, is proud to endorse the notable professional efforts and accomplishments of Laura Shorette. A member in good standing, Ms. Shorette parlays years of experience into her professional network, and has been noted for achievements, leadership abilities, and the credentials she has provided in association with her Worldwide Branding membership. About Laura Shorette: Founded in 2001 by Laura Shorette, Time Logistics, Inc. is a freight management provider (3pl) specializing in logistics planning and distribution solutions. The company partners with its customers to provide transportation expertise in the multimodal shipping supply chain as well as offer cross-dock, warehouse and fulfillment services. Time Logistics, Inc. is the first vendor to win three consecutive years in a row the Walmart supplier excellence award. Ms. Shorette is also a member of TIA, WBENC, Smart way, DMA PCC, GSA, Women's Cable Networking of Nashville, the Maury Count Alliance and the Columbia chamber of commerce. As the president and founder, she has expanded the company to a new facility that has five divisions, including retail inserts, mail distribution/direct mail, warehousing, fulfillment and general commodities. She is always looking for opportunities to grow her company. Ms. Shorette began her career as a switchboard operator at a Virginia logistics company. She worked here for 17 years, eventually being promoting to vice president of operations, before deciding to establish Time Logistics, Inc in 2001. Worldwide Branding has added Laura Shorette to their distinguished Registry of Executives, Professionals and Entrepreneurs. While inclusion in Worldwide Branding is an honor, only small selections of members in each discipline are endorsed and promoted as leaders in their professional fields. About Worldwide Branding For more than 15 years, Worldwide Branding has been the leading, one-stop-shop, personal branding company, in the United States and abroad. From writing professional biographies and press releases, to creating and driving Internet traffic to personal websites, our team of branding experts tailor each product specifically for our clients' needs. From health care to finance to education and law, our constituents represent every major industry and occupation, at all career levels. For more information, please visit http://www.worldwidebranding.com. # # # Read more Press Releases from Ellen Campbell: Aaron Arutunian Recognized by Worldwide Branding for Excellence in Information Security Dottie Corsillo Recognized by Worldwide Branding for Excellence in Steel Fabrication Kacey L. Vencill Recognized by Worldwide Branding for Excellence in IT Consulting Francie Koehler Recognized by Worldwide Branding for Excellence in Private Investigation Glenn Bolton Recognized by Worldwide Branding for Excellence in Event Management Comment on this story... Who We Are More Issues Article Comments Your Email Recipient's Email Message (Optional) Send Cancel Entrepreneurship and Innovation Resurgent in New Jersey Laurie Petersen | November 8, 2016 Business incubators, venture capital, labs and tools, and entrepreneurial expertise are fast becoming available across the Garden State It’s almost become an adage: New Jersey was once the center of innovation in the country but no longer. That title is now held by California, or Massachusetts, or New York, or even Washington. But recently, funding, professional support, and office space for entrepreneurs have been springing up all over the state — for those who know where to find them. Universities are helping to lead the way. A number of New Jersey universities are seeing it as part of their role to encourage business incubation. For instance, Anne-Marie Maman, executive director of the year-old Princeton Entrepreneurship Council, says her organization provides tools and training to foster entrepreneurs and an entrepreneurial mindset. University commitment from the very top has been proceeding at a rapid pace unusual for higher education. Support for students, faculty, and alumni includes tech space at the Princeton Entrepreneurship Hub, technology licensing opportunities, and an open-ended venture fund. Next year PEC will open an Innovation Center — offering wet labs (for pharma), dry labs (for electrical engineering), as well as co-working space to support faculty members, students, alumni, and the local community. Further north at Montclair State University, former Verizon President and CEO Dennis Bone leads the Feliciano Center for Entrepreneurship. According to Bone, entrepreneurial thinking is an essential survival skill for anyone in this world of rapid change — identifying problems that need fixing and collaborating on solutions. The Feliciano Center hosts many seminars and workshops open to the general public for learning and networking. They focus on all aspects of entrepreneurship. Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken last August opened the Stevens Venture Center to provide workspace, prototype lab, and networking opportunities for Stevens-affiliated entrepreneurs. It’s housed in the same waterfront building directly across from New York City as Jet.com, the e-commerce startup Walmart acquired for $3 billion in September. In the model of Silicon Valley (infused with talent from Stanford University) or the Route 128 corridor of Cambridge (with proximity to MIT), the idea is to create a culture that sparks innovation and creates jobs by connecting like-minded people to resources. Tech entrepreneur Aaron Price launched Propeller last May as a way to bring New York and New Jersey innovation communities and funders together on Hoboken’s Pier A. Some of the more visible efforts to link business innovation to a supporting ecosystem are happening in downtown Newark — where Amazon-owned Audible is pouring financial and intellectual capital into attracting and mentoring businesses to bring jobs and economic revival to the city. (A comprehensive list of resources has been compiled by the NJIT Innovation Acceleration Center.) Over in Holmdel, the legendary Bell Labs space (the length of three football fields) is being reborn as BellWorks, and private developers are creating a self-contained environment to work, play, and innovate. New Jersey’s future economic vitality is linked to entrepreneurial innovation, coordinating and leveraging resources, noted Michele Siekerka, president and CEO of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, at its recent Innovation Summit at the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory. “New Jersey was the Innovation State. New Jersey is the Innovation State,” she said. “Collaboration between industry, academia, and government is essential.” Elsewhere throughout the state NJIT, Rutgers, Rowan, and Seton Hall are expanding support of entrepreneurship and see it as a way to attract the best and brightest while preparing these students to thrive in the “gig economy.” The New Jersey Business Incubation Network offers a community of experts and facilities (many affiliated with community colleges) for both early-stage and expansion-stage startups. Despite all the activity, not everyone is impressed. David Sorin, partner in McCarter & English, LLP, says New York universities are running circles around their New Jersey counterparts by providing real funding for students to start real businesses. It’s the logical evolution of “career services” when a clearcut path no longer exists to graduate, join an established corporation, and enjoy a safe and steady lifetime career. Rowan started a $5 million innovation fund in 2014. Rutgers Business School is part of Newark Venture Partners, which will soon take applications to fund a second round of companies. Kathleen Coviello, director of technology and life sciences for the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, says the 500th angel investment has been approved since the state established the angel investment tax credit three years ago. (Entrepreneurs can follow this link to apply for NJEDA funding.) NJEDA also operates an incubator in North Brunswick for life sciences companies that can’t build labs on their own and offers tax credits through the Grow NJ assistance program. Katherine O’Neill, executive director of the JumpStart New Jersey Angel Network, says more than $50 million has been invested since 2002 in Mid-Atlantic region companies — close to half in New Jersey. JumpStart angels typically invest between $200,000 and $500,000 but only if there’s value to add in the form of introductions, category expertise, or other ways to accelerate growth. (Follow this link for more information on how to apply.) Investors are looking for businesses whose owners show an open mind and the ability to iterate quickly and have a team with a track record of success. Jim Gunton, general partner at the NJTC Venture Fund, recommends persistence. A rejection today can turn into success tomorrow. What’s the best way to connect with an investor? Personal introductions from accountants and attorneys who know your business are key to opening doors. NJBIA Innovation Summit keynote Bob Hugin, executive chairman of Summit-based pharmaceutical company Celgene Corp., says it took 17 years for the company to become profitable and New Jersey tax law allowing the sale of losses kept it in the game. Today, Celgene’s market capitalization is $80 billion. Laurie Petersen is a writer, editor, and event organizer based in Hoboken. Click here for reuse options! Great Bend Post Great Bend News, Opinion, Video Local News Sports Events Entertainment Other Trading Post Obituaries Great Bend Eats Ernie’s Bar & Grill Granny’s Kitchen Kiowa Kitchen Lone Wolf Restaurant Playa Azul The Rack Billiard Cafe Employment Wall After much debate, Great Bend chooses to add more income-based housing November 7, 2016 by Cole Reif 7 Comments The Great Bend City Council determined the push for new housing development outweighed the concerns of a few landlords, and passed a Rural Housing Incentive District for phase two of The Reserves at Trail Ridge near Walmart. The RHID awards tax credits to the developer, Overland Property Group, for building new housing in rural areas from the Kansas Housing Resources Corporation. Matt Gillam, Vice President of Development for the developer based out of Leawood, told the city council Monday night that the RHID is needed to bring the additional 48 units to towns like Great Bend. Matt Gillam Audio https://www.greatbendpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/reserve-gillam.mp3 At the October 3 meeting, council member Mike Zinn brought up the point that the current 48-unit apartment complex that opened in August of 2015 has seen more than its fair share of criminal activity. Great Bend Police Chief Cliff Couch says over the past year his department has received 163 calls for cases involving civil issues, domestic violence, and arrest warrants. Couch also noted that this activity is not unfamiliar with income-restricted housing. Cliff Couch Audio https://www.greatbendpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/reserve-couch.mp3 The Reserves at Trail Ridge noted they currently have 11 vacancies but that was mostly due to chosen evictions and hope to have the troublesome residents removed. Great Bend Housing Authority High Rise and many other property owners like Jason Mayers from MPIRE Property Management mentioned an increase in rental vacancies since the apartment complex on Grant Street opened. High Rise Executive Director Lynn Fleming went on to say there was no need for more income-based housing in town. Despite more criticism from a crowd member, Mayor Mike Allison said the housing development can make Great Bend become a more viable city for future business. Mike Allison Audio https://www.greatbendpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/reserve-allison.mp3 The Great Bend City Council approved the RHID with a 6-2 vote. Council members Zinn and Brock McPherson voted against the motion.
